review:
Cons: Biggest weakness of this laptop is the 1080p display. It is not IPS and has a horrendous viewing angle. The computer has cut outs for the mic and Camera and is just an empty cavity.

Pros: Cheap. Snappy processing. Preloaded with windows 10. Has everything my Mom wanted in a laptop. The Fit and finish quality is decent.

Bought this computer about 3 weeks ago and I must say I am impressed the computer works flawlessly!! Super power house computer.. And it's one of the few laptops these days that still comes with a built in disc drive making it a great computer for games as well as office work.. Would highly recommend this computer for the price and it's about $100 cheaper on here than best buy!! Amazon never fails, great product would recommend over buying a Sony or Toshiba any day of the week!!

Don't buy!!! This thing is garbage. Out of box you have to install Windows then it says bad ipad config. Thankfully had an iPad mini to look up how to fix. Then within first 24 hours the damned thing  crashes!!!! Couldn't get anything to work.had to do system restore to factory and guess what?? Bad ipad config again! Save yourself the headache and buy something else.

The computer itself (Keyboard, mouse position, size) its all good
But the font and zoom is weird
Im 18 so I don't have a vision problem. But the tabs are almost too small to see! and the skype is just fuzzy enough to be annoying. If I try zooming in  just a bit its way too huge. I don't like toshibas because they always fall apart but if I had known the screen resolution was going to be this weird I would have gotten that one.

I pre-ordered 2 in mid August and they arrived last week after they were released. That being said, I cannot speak about long term use, however the pros and cons I've found so far:

First the cons:
- I had to submit a claim for a replacement only a few hours after opening 1 of the laptops. The touch pad completely stopped working while setting up the computer. No food or drinks were involved, it just started to get spotty then stop working all together.  A mouse could fix this, however if a problem happened within the first few hours, I was worried it could happen again to another feature. Overall the touch pad feels a little cheap.
- (This is my personal mistake) I should have went with a laptop with a faster processor. There's no doubt in your mind that it's an i3 processor. I don't know if they should use "powerful" in the description as it could be misleading.

The pros:
- It's very sleek looking. You really can't leave fingerprint marks on it. When you open it up, the keyboard is very nice and the buttons are spaced evenly apart so you don't have to worry about clicking other keys when typing.
- It comes with 10 key. Very helpful for those who are used to using a regular keyboard.
- The screen is a good size for the price. For this price, the 11" screens are more often seen.
- Quality of resolution is great when you're watching movies or looking at photos.
- Relatively quick setup.
- Comes with Windows 10, which seems to have gone back to making it look more like you're using a PC rather than a phone or tablet.
- Memory is higher than other laptops that are normally the same price. If you can find one that has a good size memory in this price range, they'll lack some of the features you can find with this computer.
- Upon first glance, the RAM looks easy enough to upgrade.
- It actually comes a DVD-RW/CD-RW drive. We still use this a lot so I wanted something that had it built in.
- Battery life is decent. Maybe about 3 hours, you could maybe push 4 if you're conservative on usage.

I think there are more pros than cons for this computer, however if you're going to be doing some real gaming or using some high powered programs, than I'd look into something else. It's a really nice computer for casual use though.

Very very unhappy with this laptop.. Came with stripped screws, HDD did was not detected after it was working fine after a restart because Windows 10 preloaded could not be installed.  had no help from ASUS support.  Once it was working on and off the laptop shuts off with 70-100% battery and cannot be powered back on with and without the charger...

A nice solid laptop. For the price you can't expect much, the pre-order price made a it a no brainer, you would be hard pressed to find another laptop sub $400 with a full 1080p display. Battery life seems to be about 3 hours from my experience, that's a combo of installing application, web browsing and writing code.

If you don't have any intention of gaming, you will find this to be a wonderful laptop. The integrated Intel, while they are progressing, can't hold a candle to a real dedicated GPU. Battery life isn't as great as I was hoping, but not bad. It can still be mobile, but not the 5-6 hours I've had in a nice quad core i7 mac book pro from way back in 2011. The hard drive does seem fast enough for normal use. Keyboard is okay, not great but seems to work for what I need.

Pros
1080p <-- this is what pushes it to the top of the budget laptops in my book. (developer)
Pretty thin and lite.
Enough processing power.
Enough memory.

Cons, not really cons just really considerations.
It's a mobile i3, not for heavy processing.
4gb of memory, I routinely see 60-70% usage
5,400rpm drive, not a deal breaker but in the world of SSD's, its pretty slow.
Trackpad feels pretty cheap.

There is some extra junk installed, but it wasn't hard to remove. I have since ordered another 4gb stick of memory and a SSD but have not installed it yet. From what I've found out the upgrade process is a lot more work than it should be. Also I have not been able to find any real specs or manual online or in the box for this specific model to tell you things like, the max memory supported etc.

This is all subjective to my experience, your mileage will vary.

After having read my review, it's pretty indecisive. I want to say that for normal day to day use, it will serve you well. Just no gaming or heavy processing.
My little one loves her new laptop.  SHe does lots of minecrafting, video editing, and graphic design. This laptop is just what she wanted. Fast enough for her!

Main takeaway: I'm very pleased with the purchase overall and highly recommend it to anyone who needs a laptop for everyday usage.  Remember especially that many people over-buy or get talked into things they don't need.  The i3 in this system is more than capable of performing the majority of tasks most users will require of it.  Gamers who need a video card capable of running the latest and greatest new releases will need to look elsewhere, but this laptop should be fine for anyone who will be mostly surfing the internet, watching streaming videos, listening to music, writing emails, working with word processing, etc.

Remember that buying it with certain credit cards (American Express, Visa Signature, others?) will automatically double the manufacturer's 12 month warranty.

Pros:

- At $350 shipped, it's essentially a $300 laptop with specs appropriate to the price and a $50 full-HD 1080p screen.  Maybe the market is moving to HD at this price point, but I doubt there are many systems out there with these specs/screen at this price.  I was considering a Chromebook or the like, but for $100 (or less) I got a fully functional PC with a full HD screen.  Wow.

- Battery life after unpacking and charging overnight shows 4.5 hours on the battery  saver setting.  I suspect 3-4 hours is probably realistic once it's being used.

- The screen looks great with a bit of light bleeding on the bottom edge of mine.  It's only noticeable in a dark room while watching a dark movie, so I'm possibly being overly critical.  Again, $350, and wow.  The viewing angles are okay but I'm sure they'd look horrible if placed next to a $2000 laptop.

- Not a touch screen.  That may be in the "con" section for some, but I've got an ultrabook that I never, ever use the touchscreen on.  I'm sort of glad this one doesn't have it in order to minimize failures and faults that could potentially be associated with it.

- Touchpad - Most importantly, it doesn't appear to interfere with or affect typing.  The left and right buttons are incorporated into the design and there is no edge between them.  The buttons have a fairly loud click when used, although the touchpad can be used when a bit more silence is desired or required.

- Keyboard feels good even though it doesn't have the tactile feedback I prefer.  It's positioned well overall and is responsive.

- Windows 10 will take some adjusting to, but I am fairly impressed with how quickly it boots even with the factory 5400RPM hard drive.

- RAM has a hatch for easy upgrading (see photo), and there's an empty slot available to add another stick.  Remove the little circular plug cover to expose a screw, then you can remove the cover.  I've attached CPU-Z info and screengrabs of the RAM and SSD upgrades recommended by Crucial using their scanner.  I'm not recommending or endorsing them, just offering the data in case anyone needs it or wants to cross reference with other drives/RAM that may fit.

- The lid is plastic and textured very subtly, so no fingerprints.

Cons:

- Bare bones 4GB RAM and 500GB 5400RPM HDD, although I'm certain that's a large part of the reason they can sell at this price.

- HDD is not easy to replace.  There is a video on youtube titled "Asus F555L Disassembly for Hard Disk Replacement" that shows how, but it's not as easy as it could be, unfortunately.  It appears that the lower cover is structural now, so be careful when you take it apart.

- A bit of flex in the keyboard, but I don't think it's inappropriate for a laptop in this price range.

- No discs for factory restore or option to create them with Asus software that I could find, so be sure to use the Windows backup option as soon as you receive the system.  Search for "file history" and Backup and Restore (Windows 7).
Broken in a year
Unfortunately a bad bargain -too slow despite a memory upgrade and worst of all a very bad screen.  Should have known  better!!

My hard drive had to replaced after one year, with a cost of $100.00 to repair. the computer started to run slow and abruptly shut down. I think this computer is just alright, but I think it should have lasted longer. I primarily used this computer for light school work, and internet search with no gaming at all. Would I buy again? I always buy Asus computers and have had good luck with them, but I think Asus is having quality issues and feel at this price point that there are better computers out there to consider.

This might be the slowest, worse computer I have ever seen.  Nuff said. I wish I had sent it back the same day.
There is NO multi-tasking ability at all.  From the Wi-Fi to the hard drive it's sloooowwww.

Very good
I am satisfied with the product.

I got this as a back up.  It works fine and does what a Windows laptop should do.  I'm just a little disappointed because it came configured with the hard drive split into two logical drives.  I also find the product support a little iffy.  (very slow to respond and hard to reach).
There was little to no documentation (that's somewhat common these days).

It was great for the first year and a few months. After that, everything went downhill. It is slow to load programs, a screw came loose - twice (I tightened it and yet it came off a day or two later), and it has been having WiFi connection problems the past few months.

This computer is okay for the price, but Id try something different. The placement/sensitivity of the mouse is infuriating. While typing, my hands will be contacting the mouse which will then highlight what Im typing and then delete it all. The computer doesnt seem capable of keeping up with fast typists. The speakers are not very loud, and the scroll function does not work.

However, the battery life has been excellent and it never overheats. The laptop does its job for its price range.

For the price  it's fine . One thing I like is that it stays cool ALL OF THE TIME. I mean almost cold even after being on for a constant 24 hours, don't know how thy do it.
Two things I don't like is that there is no light to show if you have CAPS on or off. You can set up a sound to let you know but i still don't know if the beep means that it's caps on or caps off. So a light would be good.
 The second dislike is the mouse pad. I  look at my keys when I type and occasionally I look up and I see that  I'm typing in the middle of a previous sentence .Either the shirt cuff or the heal of my palm rubs on the pad and shifts the cursor alot unbeknownst to me.
That's it. Again for the price  , it's fine
One last thing , get yourself some extra RAM  , it needs it and your dog could change it for you . Yes it's that simple. Hers what you need.  Crucial 8GB Single DDR3/DDR3L 1600 MT/S (PC3-12800) Unbuffered SODIMM 204-Pin Memory - CT102464BF160B
Bought it for a friend, and in one day the machine locked out and its a piece of crap

In the 18 months since I bought this, it has had bootup problems to the point where I had to send it back to the manufacturer 3 times. This last time, ASUS claimed the warranty is out so they won't do anything, even though its been an ongoing problem. Fortunately I bought squaretrade's replacement plan so I will get it fixed again, but I'll only have it as a back-up computer from now on. I used this computer to run windows office, web browsers, and a couple of small engineering programs such as HEC-RAS. When this computer does work, it manages these things fine, but it really craps out a lot. Also ASUS customer service is abysmal. The first time it broke down they had it for two weeks, then sent it back to me saying they fixed the LED screen. There was never a problem with the screen, and they didn't fix the boot problems so I had to send it right back to them, getting charged for shipping both times. I ended up not having my computer for a month, which is extremely inconvenient for a student like myself. I will never buy an ASUS product again, and you shouldn't either.

Start up is extremely slow.  I also needed to add RAM to make it more usable for even day to day tasks.  I knew it wasn't a powerhouse when purchased but was surprised by how slow it was.  Worst part was that I have had to send it back twice for repairs.  Once for a bad wireless adapter.  That was fixed but it came back from the repair facility with a flickering screen that could not be fixed via firmware updates or reinstalling firmware.  Previous ASUS laptops were way better than this.

Absolutely horrible! Freezes constantly and crashes even when just using word.  My high school student uses this only for homework and it has been a nightmare. He's had to redo several essays because word won't save his documents because of the freezing and crashing issues.
Good speed and storage for a light use laptop. Not too heavy.

I purchased this laptop about 18 months ago based on the price at the time and the good reviews on Amazon for it. Looks like the average review rating has dropped significantly since I bought it with a lot more 1 star ratings. Maybe they had the same problem I had. I give it a 2 star, the laptop worked fine for me up until last week when all of the sudden the screen just went white with interspersed gray lines. Of course, I am out of the 1-year warranty period. Basically, they just don't make 'em like they used to. I didn't even use the product all that much. It's sad you can't get more than 18 months out of a moderate level laptop.

Only negative that I can think of is that the camera is terrible. Its not high quality and isn't HD. <--- TAKE NOTE
Worked great at first but didn't last. I guess you get what you pay for
Im happy with this purchase. It does everything I need it to. Occasionally it makes a buzzing sound when I watch a lot of movies. But great for everyday use.
Excellent
Stopped working in one year. Amazon nor Asus willing to repair or replace. All this after the first had to be returned  as it was received damaged. Made me lose my faith in Asus products.
Happy with this computer very clear screen.
Slower than I expected for a new laptop.  I am going to get a new battery for my old HP and use this one as a back up only.
It's been great, no negatives.  Reasonably priced.
Basic laptop that looks cool, no complaints.. Don't expect to play triple A gaming titles on it.

I have never bought a ASUS before but I really love how easy to use this computer is.  I am not really that into technology so personally I need something user friendly and this works perfect for me !
good one
Bought it for mum, she seems pleased after using it for a year now.
I had this for over two years and I upgraded the Hard Drive to the Samsung SSD 250Gig and add additional 8 Gig of RAM to it. It boot up m quicker and still running great.

Laptop was pretty decent at doing light tasks. Have owned it almost 2 years now, but last night the thing exploded in my livingroom while I was running updates. I had to toss it outside to prevent further damage inside my house.

I have had this computer only 2 years, and I'm now looking at replacing the motherboard for the second time due to charging/battery issues.  It would cost more than I paid for it to replace the motherboard, so I will just buy a new laptop.  Needless to say, it won't be an ASUS!

I'm not a computer nerd. I cannot speak specs. But all I was looking for was a simple laptop, store some pictures and music on it. Use it occasionally for real word processing with a keyboard.

I got a nice shiny clamshell that take 10 minutes to boot up and then lags the entire time I attempt to work on it.

Had virus protection on since day one. Am using a fraction of the hard drive and even added additional RAM. It's basically a brick 18 months later......
great laptop

Wow.. I can't believe people leave 4 and 5 star reviews for this laptop.
Performance of this hardware configuration on Windows 10 is absolutely horrible.
I had the 100% disk usage problem and couldn't solve it. None of the solutions published on the Internet worked for me..
As a result I had a very slow machine out of box.

E.g.
Restart 1m 08s
Login 35s
Open Notepad 10s

Windows 10 will eat 2 Gb RAM after a fresh start.
Every Chrome tab will cost you an extra 300 Mb. With CNN, FOX, Amazon, Gmail, Facebook and YouTube open in separate tabs, you will have 3.4 Gb used. And at this point the system becomes practically non-responsive.

WiFi connection drops intermittently and I could never connect to WiFi at work no matter what I did.

Battery life barely sustains 4 hrs of light work.

Installing Linux Mint makes this machine much more robust, however not enough to say 'wow'.

Verdict. This laptop is not a ready out-of-box solution. Needs at least 4 Gb RAM extra.
Works Great
Great laptop while it lasted but sadly after only a year and a hand the mother board went out on it.
Had it for two years and still works great.

i loved this laptop! Mind you, i added 8gb of additional memory and switch it to a 250 ssd before ever using the hardwarr it came with. So, i could have a biased opinion, but i really enjoyed the ability to customize it like i did!
i got this with the intent of using it for photo editing, and it easily ran Photoshop, bridge, my browser and other such extra without issue. (with the gear i put inti it)

Shame someone stole it from me, ah! Back when i bought it in 2016, it was going for $360, i don't know what happened to increase the price by nearly $150, especially since a new model came out. Maybe this was reissued, and i missed something. Either way, great computer.

When I initially got the laptop, I was excited and ready to embark on all the exciting new features that a newer piece of hardware could provide (I was used to doing everything off my 2010 iMac). The initial boot-up was phenomenal and everything worked beautifully!
Then, about 6 months into regular use, my hard drive crashed and never recovered. Upon calling Asus tech support, I realized that because my "6" key on my number pad was missing and I had a few surface scratches, that they would not repair my laptop at their closest repair center to me, which is in Georgia, but instead, required me to ship it out to California to their main repair branch. So what looked like a 4 day max operation turned into an almost 2 week long wait to get something as simple as a hard drive replaced (which also took them 2 days to do, on top of the 10 TOTAL day shipping).
Not to mention, the laptop as is will not be a gaming machine unless you like running all your games on low settings due to the motherboard having Intel 5500 integrated HD graphics. And the hard drive is dated, and I mean DATED! The hard drive itself isn't even running at 7,200 RPM and is instead a 500 GB HGST hard drive from around 2013 operating at 5,400 RPM. The processor is weak, but gets most tasks done. The screen is phenomenal. The sound on the laptop is pretty nice as well, so I would say there are some good sides to this machine.
Also, if you want more RAM, just buy a 4GB or 8GB 204 pin DDR3L stick and this computer will be able to handle a heavier load considering that Windows 10 on this machine uses about 3.5 GB of the 4GB you're given at purchase. There is a compartment on the back that you have to unscrew and open to add in the new RAM as well, but there are YouTube videos for that kind of thing!
priced well, did what I needed it to do
I've had this computer for 10 months. It's only been lightly used and constantly freezes & has a low pitched buzz every 2-3 minutes. It's an absolute piece of junk...

It is a good computer over all. quiet and do what it should do. Of course you don't want to do hardcore gaming, audio/video formating etc. However, for general usages such as website surfing, email, office works, this is great.
Only one and big downside is that the wifi connection, only wifi not wired connection, is not great.
In fact wifi connection is very annoying; system(OS) wifi status says wifi is connected, but the web itself is disconnected. and then it comes back on after couple minutes. this short disconnection repeats continuously. I have tried this in my house, coffee shop, library, etc. but all same situation. I have feeling that the wifi hardware is not a good one because I have done things I can do software wise.

Finally my two laptops  Asus F555LA-AB31 and Asus x551 are dead..
I am disappointed with the outcome.
We have two of them now and we love it.

I have had this computer for a year and a half. For the first month or seemed great. However, problems began slowly. The CD drive would skip, but I barely watch DVDs so it wasn't a big problem. Then it started to blue screen every time I watched a YouTube video. It's very slow. I can't stay connected to the internet so working on googledocs is impossible. Now the mouse freezes so I have to press the power button, then re login and then I get another minute or two of using the mouse before I have to start the process over again. At this point I have done a factory reset but it's still not working.

This has been the absolutely WORST laptop I have ever owned! If I could send it back I would. Don't waste your money, it may seem cheap, but in the long run your sanity is worth more than you will save on this pile of crap.
The keyboard is a nightmare. Within 2 months of buying this thing I started noticing strange keyboard anomalies. They got considerably worse and have now rendered the thing useless. You will be typing along and suddenly hit a normal key and everything you just typed will disappear, or hit a key and suddenly all of your toolbar items will start flashing before you. Keys routinely fail to work or cause inexplicable things to happen. The disappearing text has caused me enormous stress. At least once a week the thing just goes black. You can hear it revving but the screen goes black and nothing you do can get it to come back on other then a hard shutdown and waiting 30  minutes. The battery time is useless. I could only go about 30-45 minutes before the batt died. I thought HP was useless, this thing has far surpassed all the trouble I had with the last HP and customer service sucks. Stuck with a totally useless waste of money. Never again.
ASUS leaves a lot to be desired. The wireless card software needs to be updated. All hardware software should be updated.
This laptop is better than I expected it to be I have had no problems with it so far, it's not the cheapest but it's not extremely expensive either so I like it
Good cheap laptop. ASUS is the best brand, I buy only ASUS laptops. They are solidly built and have good components.

Hard drive failed right after unit's warranty expired. Bought in June of 2016, started getting the "S.M.A.R.T. Status Bad, Backup and Replace" message at start-up, which means the hard disk is caput.  I see that there are many others reporting problems with this unit. Of course the manufacturer's warranty has conveniently just expired.
very very good

~330$ for a full-sized Asus laptop seemed like a good deal. But, comparing with my last Asus (purchased 2009, ~$700, still runs, I eventually had to replace because I dropped it and plastic cracked, exposing wires), I feel like I should have saved up for something that might last a bit longer.

This computer is only a year old, and I took about 6 months to get around to using it. I've never dropped it or spilled anything on it, so it should run perfectly. However:
a) three screws have come loose from the bottom of the computer. I tried screwing them back in but they wouldn't stay. So I examined them and found they'd all been undermined by a line of blue paint, which is also in the computer. Poor manufacturing! If I lose one more screw the base will come apart :)
b) there's something wrong with the sound (issue began after only 3 months of use). it seems to be a driver problem -- while any type of audio is playing through any speakers/headphones, I periodically get a bluescreen which says "dpc watchdog violation." Supposedly easy to correct: update drivers, or uninstall/reinstall. But the problem persists despite my efforts. Based on a number of random audio symptoms, and the ineffectiveness of software fixes, I'm beginning to wonder whether the problem isn't hardware-related
c) The other day I got an orange (!) screen for the first time ever. Apparently this means an issue with graphics card, too? Whatever!
d) The computer has always run relatively slowly. This may be a result of Windows' bloatware, but that's part of what you're buying here. (You have to jump through a ton of hoops to delete programs as an administrator these days.)

My point is, I've wasted a lot of time coddling this stupid machine. It's very young to be having so many problems. It runs, but at what cost...

If you want a quickly disposable computer, this is the way to go. Not worth 300+ imho

When I first got it, i experiences all the positive reviews and really loved what I got for the price. However, it started running slowly sometimes after six months. I uninstalled some programs and reinstalled windows multiple times, until one day it started crashing constantly (blue screen). I've had two RMAs with Asus. The first one was the laptop's HDD not being recognized; whenever I turned it on it would stay on the Aptio Setup Utility as if there was no hard drive to boot from. They sent it back saying a keyboard component was replaced; which was obviously wrong since it crashed 30 minutes after I turned it back on. I sent it back the second time and they replaced the motherboard; it was working fine for a couple of days and now it's back to crashing. After the second RMA, I had already ran out of my one-year warranty and could not afford to send it back to the repair shop so now I'm currently saving up for a new laptop.

It's possible that I was unlucky and received a bad model, and I will say that Asus has very fast customer support. Unfortunately, mines was not worth all the trouble.
My dad love this computer. It's a good product.
Worked fine but it didn't last long, 1.5 years.
3 bad screens

Bought this laptop in March 2016 and it started giving us trouble in in 18 months.  Laptop makes a buzzing sound after running for a few mins and then shuts down.  Very dissatisfied with the Asus laptop.  We are not going to buy this again
Laptop freezes up when watching movies eg  Netflix. I haven't even tried to use a processor heavy programme like premiere pro or light room yet...waste.
Very good product with reasonable price.  Great value for the price paid.  purchased about a year back and it is still working very nice.

Right now, the price of this laptop is more than what I paid for it. I paid less that $400 when I purchased this a year ago. It's not worth the price now with DDR3 when you can get similar laptops now with DDR4 and a 7th gen intel processor.

With that said..

The laptop in it's original state is a little slow, but that's mostly because the lack of ram and the slow 5200rpm hard drive. I added an additional 4GB of ram and a Samsung 850 Evo solid state drive. It's now on par with higher end, dual core laptops. Solid State Drives and ram are must haves.

Out of the box, I've had nothing but issues with this laptop. Slow, unresponsive at times, and just an overall headache. Should have returned it originally but life tends to get in the way. Do not recommend.
If your looking to run cpu intensive games, this won't do. Matter of fact, most gaming won't do. But it is a steady workhorse for me, and I just need a dedicated work machine for the road.
I have been on computers since 1987 and this piece of garbage crashes more often than any computer I've ever owned.  AVOID.

I bought this laptop a year and a half ago, and it's already working slow. the sound won't work unless I update it, and I can't play movies off it either. Not worth it. I wish I would have bought an apple laptop at this point. I was able to get my school work done on it, but not to the best ability. When the sound does work, it's very quiet too.

I purchased the laptop on January 14, 2016.  On August 9, 2017, the monitor, videocard, or possibly the motherboard, crashed and rendered the laptop unusable.  It is not possible to tell what is wrong without paying for expert assistance.  Although the warranty is 12 months, I did expect a little more time before a probable-fatal error.  I'm repeatedly reminded that Apple is a better product.

This laptop sucks. I bought it approximately a year ago based on the stellar reviews and it being on the bestseller list on Amazon. I thought it must be good, right? Well, I was wrong. After only a year of using it, it started having this problem where it would suddenly freeze while watching videos and then automatically shut off and restart with an error message that says DPC Watchdog Violation. I contacted customer support and they advised me to reset the computer. I did that but the problem persisted. So I will have to contact them again. However, I do regret buying this laptop and I feel like next time, I should have bought a more expensive laptop that was more reputable instead of saving on this one. And don't tell me that this is a random issue because now Ive seen other customers issues and there is no way its random if so many customers are experiencing problems as well! Ive noticed that the reviews are a lot less positive than a year ago, which says a lot about how this laptop functions long-term. It must be some defect in the computer/poor quality control which may disturbingly be intentional. Either way, I will not buy from this brand again!

This laptop is garbage & ASUS repair customer service is poor.  They advise 5 days from receipt to repair or replace.  It has been 5 weeks and a supervisor can't even promise you they will approve a replacement.  Do not purchase this product.
No complaints!!!
good.
the best computer for more less money buy. Excelente, I recomend.
Not the best quality but good for the price
Nice computer.
After 14 months, motherboard went! Never again will I order this Durand!

I HAVE ENJOY MY ASUS FOR SEVERAL YEARS NOW AND LIKE THE CLEAR PICTURES, EASY SURFING, FAST WEBBING AND MANY OTHER NICE FUN THINGS!!  I RECOMMEND IT TO ANYONE, OUTSIDE OF ADULTS... IT IS GREAT FOR COLLEGE ENTRANTS AS WELL AS HIGH SCHOOL AND YOUNGER CHILDREN!!
had a lot of problems with this at first...had to actually send it back to the company twice!

See Update at bottom:
Purchased in April 2016, died in May 2016 - one month past the one year warranty date.  Took it to a repair shop and was told it needed to have the motherboard replaced at a cost of $527.  I won't buy an ASUS again.  The only advice I would give to anyone brave enough to buy one of these is to buy the Amazon extended warranty.
Update 28 August, 2017 - My previous review was picked up by an ASUS representative who promptly contacted me to let me know that the unit should not have failed so soon out of warranty and offered to repair it under warranty anyway.  Once I received an RMA I packaged it up and sent it along.  Unit was repaired and back in my hands in less than 10 days.  I changed my review to 5-stars because there aren't many companies that I've encountered that will do what ASUS did.
Very good laptop.

I got this laptop with somewhat high hopes. I needed it to browse internet, stream shows via my cable company website and for sites like Cricut, a design space for crafting. I don't use it frequently. I had one repair done within the first year due to the fact that the chord stopped charging the laptop, tech support was okay and mailing it in to get it fixed within the warranty time was pretty painless. However, now it freezes and makes a grinding sound so that I have to hard reboot it. This tends to happen while watching videos or streaming. Also the mouse icon will fail to show up when I turn it on, and I have to keep hard rebooting it until the mouse icon appears AND actually works, since sometimes it appears but won't move when I try to use the touch pad. Thought about buying a mouse but aggravated that I have to. I'm not even sure I want to deal with tech support again simply b/c it's time consuming and I'm aggravated that a gently used device is so much trouble. Bought this in April 2016, it's 13 months later, and just never felt the laptop was able to handle what I do which doesn't seem like much and it has not been used frequently by any means.

Purchased this laptop less than a year ago and it is barely, if at all, working anymore. Worse purchase I've made in a very long time. Won't buy another ever. It is sleek! It had a great display with HD screen. It was wonderful....for about 4 months. Since then it not much more than an aggravation!

Model was not made for Windows 10, can not handle "Antimalware Service Executable" Contacted ASUS for support, they gave me a ticket, but ignored my request. Can't update the Intel drivers as ASUS has made hardware "proprietary" I am absolutely disgusted with ASUS over this, have been using their motherboards for years to build my own towers.

I purchased my laptop in July of 2016.  Worked fine for nearly a year, however on June 28, 2017 It died.  It would not turn on.  My husband asked a tech friend to look at it and he said the motherboard was shot.  I checked the warranty and although I am 2 weeks under the expiration the warranty does not cover the motherboard.  I am baffled as to what went wrong.  The laptop never left the house and I check email, read the news & weather and shop on amazon.  I am very disappointed.  I am currently writing this on a 7 year old pc.  Brand or just bad luck.  I can't say but would not buy this again.

I bought this labtop because this was the only labtop left that has a DVD/CD player. I've purchased a similar Asus labtop before in the past, so I decided to get one almost the same. I truly HATE this computer which is a surprise as I have been a loyal fan of all computers ASUS. I have had three ASUS computers and or tablets over the years and of course when it came to upgrading my current computer I naturally gravitated towards ASUS after all they had always been an excellent buy. Not this time. From the first day I noticed that the computer was particularly slow especially when it came to surfing the internet. At first I thought that maybe there was a lot of traffic on the web so I thought nothing of it. The next time the same thing happened. It took ages buffering before it could open any page. So out of curiosity I whipped out my older ASUS laptop/tablet and logged onto the same site I had been waiting eons for this new laptop to open. Presto it opened in an instant. I surfed to my hearts content and when i was finished and had shut down that older laptop this new horrible contraption still had not loaded the page! Still not wanting to draw any firm conclusion yet I decided that perhaps because I had not updated somethings that may be the cause. Ergo i dutifully upgraded everything it prompted me to do. No improvement! This still takes looooooooooooooooooooooong to load anything and I have given up using it. Right now it is a rather expensive paperweight on my desk! What a waste of money!

This is one of those cases where I don't understand the negative reviews. I purchased this laptop a year ago. I installed an SSD and additional memory bringing it to 8GB. I've owned this laptop for just over a year and for the price, it's wonderful. Does everything I need it to do and I appreciate the DVD and "no camera" options very much. As well, one side of the flip-up screen has started to make a cracking noise when I open or close it, apparently it has become misaligned. I use this 99% at home, so it hasn't been handled roughly. My last laptop (a Dell) has lasted over 8 years and looks and feels just as solid and sturdy as it did the day I got it, so this feels cheap to me. (OTOH, my Dell cost 3x as much! If only XP hadn't gone by the wayside, I'd still be using it.)

Updating this review with a helpful hint: When your keys start to pop off (because the latches underneath break), QuickFix Laptop Keys has the best price, free shipping and excellent video and PDF instructions on how to install them. You will need the "series 40" keys. You're welcome.

I bought four of these back on October 2016 and since then I have had a terrible experience.  First, the keyboards for all of them just stopped responding, not all at the same time, but every keyboard stopped responding within the first three months.  To fix this, we had to go online and somehow found a fix where you had to go into the settings and turn off some random keyboard setting.  Then, one of the computers just stopped booting up and would only boot to BIOS, I had to send that back and they had to wipe the computer and reinstall the OS.  All of them have been very quirky and just do not operate smoothly.  And lastly, these things are super fragile.  When you get them they feel very cheaply made and I have already experienced two cracked screens.  I did a good deal of research before buying these and I purchased them because they got good ratings, but I would never recommend these to anyone.

I've had this laptop for over 6 months now and figured that is enough time for a review. This laptop gets me through the day for basic needs: web browsing, streaming and downloading music/videos via Youtube/ Spotify/ "new movie" websites, working on Word, Excel and Photoshop (not included). I find I can like do some work in those programs or browse the web while streaming music and downloading a video at the same time and it won't slow down the computer too much. However, if I put the laptop into "sleep" mode (while my programs are still opened) and turn it back on later, the laptop is super slow and I have to close all my programs and restart the laptop.

This laptop has a good screen size where I can do work or watch movies. The screen is 1080p so movies are pretty sharp. Weight depends on what you're used to, but I think it has an average weight where I don't mind carrying it in a backpack. Battery life is average (5 1/2 hours browsing using wi-fi).

Overall, very good bang for my buck. I'm a mid-20's professional who just needed a basic laptop for browsing, streaming/downloading and working from home sometimes without spending lots of money. If you fall into that category, this laptop is for you.

I have to reset the router every time to get this device to connect. I have done all the troubleshooting and still no progress. My mistake was not returning immediately and not paying attention to the warranty date. It's probably not worth repairing. I have bought thousands of products on Amazon through business and personal accounts. This is by far the biggest Amazon regret!

I've put off reviewing this laptop for a few months in the hopes that all the glitches would work themselves out, but that was delusional on my part.  Worst computer ever. Right from the start, the non removable battery was wonky - wouldn't hold a charge, wouldn't charge while plugged in (this seemed to get better for a while, but not any more); the keyboard and touch pad were overly sensitive, causing me to lose freshly typed paragraphs at a time; the computer runs super slow,  and Asus online customer service service is a joke. Now, after only a few months, the computer won't turn on at all. Fully charged when I shut it off last night, and this morning it's dead. No battery light (plugged in or not). Even if I wanted to return it, I can't get on to delete any info or content...

It is insanely loud when it kicks on and it kicks on and off ALL THE TIME.  After having it a little over a year the hard drive has taken a turn for the worse. The speed of the disk will make you pull your hair out. I attatched an image of a benchmark I ran on the drive before replacing it with a SSD.

It needs more RAM. You really only need 4gb extra here, I mean... what are you going to be doing on THIS laptop that will require 12gb total RAM? Save the $20 and buy a 4gb stick.

Now the good news.

It is a fantastic laptop all around for the value. I have always trusted Asus to deliver great and reliable laptops and computer components and this one has not disappointed. Keyboard feels great and the touchpad is responsive. My only gripe about the keyboard is that there are no lights indicating caps lock or num pad is on... little bit frustrating but not a deal breaker.
The screen is great and not something you see usually in this price range. (yep...that's it about the screen.)
The outside of the laptop is great, it looks wonderful closed and open. It doesn't get hot where your wrists will settle and doesn't cut into your wrists like some laptops I have had in the past.

All in all it is a good laptop and I gave it 4 stars because in all honesty if I wanted to buy a laptop and swap out the HDD for a SSD and add some RAM to make it faster... this would have been one I would have gone for. It is a great price range and has a great processor and a wonderful screen. Did I buy this one thinking that I would replace and upgrade these things? No... I did not.

Worked fine for the first 6 months then I started having wifi connectivity problems where the wireless would turn off spontaneously.  I work from home so I only need a computer that can maintain an internet connection so that I can vpn and rdp to my workstation in the office.  At 9 months old the laptop is absolutely useless.  The wifi works for ten minutes before disabling at which point the entire system freezes and I'm forced to restart.  The restart usually fails and I do a hard restart on the system.  I'm now at the point where it won't even boot.  Money well spent - if you are looking for a disposable laptop then this is it.

I'm a college student and bought this laptop around a year ago for the sole use of academic work/study. At first, it was hands down the best laptop I ever owned; it was a nice size, great resolution, high speed, portable, and extremely functional. Unfortunately, about 6 months passed and I was no longer able to use the sound. I reinstalled drivers, tried different software, and numerous other methods. Nothing worked. No big deal, I only used it for a few study videos for class and Netflix in my down time. Not a problem. Another 6 or so weeks passed and my computer has been randomly crashing ever since. More times than I can count I've lost documents, powerpoints, excel spreadsheets and more due to random systemic failures. From time to time, it'll have a period of good sportsmanship and I'm able to knock out copious amounts of work and I assume all is well and whatever problem I had before must have resolved itself. Moments later, I'm sitting in front of the screen, mouth open, desperately trying to recover work or prevent the PC from restarting itself at this immensely inconvenient time. I'm highly disappointed and dissatisfied with the quality and current state of this product. I bought this computer with the notion that ASUS was a company that prided itself on its ability to bring cost effective, quality products to consumers - built with strict standards - but apparently, I've been gravely mistaken.

So I was in the market for a 15 inch laptop since my Acer laptop went K.O for no reason. I stumbled upon this laptop and really tempted to purchase it right away, but instead I spent couple days reading all the amazon review, the good, the bad, tutorial how to upgrade the SSD and the RAM, etc.
So I pulled the trigger and bought this Asus laptop with the Crucial 8GB Ram, and used Samsung 850 EVO 250GB from ebay total investment about $440ish. Initial first impression without all the upgrade, the laptop is alright. Boot up was pretty slow, browsing the internet, and doing some work was ok not the fastest. The screen is alright for 1080p, I wish it wasn't matte finish. Speaker is pretty awesome on this laptop and even though this laptop is big, its actually pretty light weight. Battery was ok about 3-4 hours. The laptop looks good from a far but feels kind of cheap IMO.
After I installed all the upgrades, the difference is night and day. It boot up like less than 5 seconds now, battery improved a lot, the whole performance improving significantly as well makes this laptop enjoyable to use. Now I'm not a tech savvy at all, I just followed youtube direction and fellow amazon review from here. The SSD upgrade was a little bit challenging, but you just have to be patient and don't yank anything too hard.
Should you buy this laptop for $340 without all the upgrades? it depends on your daily usage. If you the type a person just need this laptop to do some work, youtube, Netflix, internet, I would say this laptop will do the job. If you care about performance, speed, battery (it improves a lot after the upgrade) then you should buy this laptop plus all the upgrades it's totally worth it.

Great all around laptop for watching movies and browsing the web.  I looked at this as a great platform to enhance for less than $100 of investment and a bit of my time.
Out of the box it boots very slowly for Windows 10 due to a super slow conventional Toshiba MQ01ABF050 500GB hard drive and only 4GB of ram.  This hamstrings an otherwise great platform.  A simple addition of a bit of ram and an SSD transform this laptop into a 2-3 second booting pleasure to live with.

Here is why I'm giving this 5 stars:
The 4GB of hynix memory is soldered onboard so you can simply buy a small 4-8GB module and 1 screw you have the memory issues sorted: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LTV2BBK is what I used.
The HDD replacement is quite easy if you are tech savvy, plenty of youtube videos to explain how to do it if you are not.  Throwing in the most basic SDD drive will transform this laptop from ~20-30 seconds booting up to 2-3 seconds.  I used an old Crucial 80GB SSD I had laying around but you can find plenty for ~$40.  So for a total of ~$100 additional investment and a bit of wrenching time you get a $600 laptop for $300.

I'd love to hold 1/4 of a star for the off/center keyboard due to the number pad but some folks like the number pad.  On a small laptop I'd prefer they give you an option to have a normal keyboard that is centered.

Thousands of other reviews on this so I'll keep it brief.  Annoyances for me were --
1) Sticking key on keyboard. Only one, but worrying how easily it can happen.
2) Keyboard layout generally awkward, esp arrow keys.  Flat keys, seemingly more-spaced-out than I'm used to. Have to watch carefully for every key press, and in subdued light very difficult to see.  I had to add a paper strip along the top to identify the special keys (speaker volume, Prt Scrn etc) more clearly.
3) Track Pad.  I should have researched Asus computers before buying - now realize this is their great Achilles Heel - very troublesome, over sensitive, have to disable all the 'multifinger swipe functions' and still the cursor can bounce around the screen.
4) 'Mouse buttons' (in touchpad) VERY 'clicky' (noisy) - gets annoying playing a game sitting next to someone (and even to myself).  They are also very spaced apart, hard to reach right-click while holding down ctrl key for example.
5) USB ports seem 'iffy' - had to jiggle my memory sticks around sometimes to get connected, (didn't have that in my Dell).
6) Win 10 is a pain in many ways. I know this isn't an Asus fault but the combination was enough for me to decide to return it within 30 days (pain-free, thanks Amazon!) and go back to my old Dell D820 with WinXP and Win7!!

Pros:
1) Screen resolution is great, which makes it possible to use the Window10 split-screen functionality and still read small text.
2) Despite the larger size, it's surprisingly light.
3) There are plenty of ports for connecting just about anything you'd want (HDMI, USB, another monitor).
4) Personally, I like that the trackpad buttons are flush with the palm rest (which does, at it advertises, keep cool).
5) The battery life is pretty decent, and charges relatively quickly.

Cons:
1) The hard drive (5400rpm) and processor are definitely on the slow side; they're good for general internet use, using office products and what I've purchased it for - running and programming in Eclipse. It's definitely not capable of some of the more resource-intense programs that I use (Adobe Creative Suite products, for example) but that's fine because I knew that prior to purchasing.
2) The keyboard area has a lot of bubble/flex in it - it doesn't really affect performance but it's definitely not solid when typing.
3) When you close the laptop, the keyboard does make some slight imprints on the screen - I've only had it for a week, so at this point I can't determine whether this would pose an actual issue (you can see these prints when the screen brightness is turned down/off).

Amazon pressed me for a review as soon as I received the product and gave it a favorable rating. This is no longer the case:

In less than a few months, the computer is no longer functional; it won't even load the BIOS screen (mind you, I don't use this computer for heavy use - just surfing the web).

I bought this laptop new, knowing there was a one-year manufacturing warranty included. What makes the purchase such a regret is so how terribly piss poor their customer service is. The time on hold, what they recommend to troubleshoot, and ultimately sending the computer back for repair was remarkably frustrating, timely, and expensive

They're not going to pay for shipping so you're out at least $60 bucks - so yes, repairs even under warranty will cost you. If I wanted to spend the extra cash to ship this lemon computer, I would've just purchased a more expensive laptop. I have to ask myself, "If I knew that this computer was dud, and that ASUS customer service was awful, would I spend the cash on their computer"?

Absolutely not. In retrospect, I wish I had given my money to Dell or Lenova. I feel I've been scammed.

Update: After ASUS returning the computer from customer service, it's still acting buggy. Just to reiterate, this computer sucks.
touchpad horrible

**1 day of use***

Having owned several laptops and desktops, here is what I think of this computer so far: it's good, not great. There are some hollow places, like under the keys, that make it seem cheap--in my mind, at least. The weight is spread so far out and I know they're trying to make it seem lighter than it is, which works with small things like phones and tablets, but not so much with laptops. I feel like I'm holding this gigantic empty shell of a computer and it's weird.

I do plan to play a few games on this--Sims 4, Neverwinter (maybe), Witcher 3, etc. I do expect a few issues with MMORPGs obviously but I'm going to try it anyway.

PROS
1. Fast: I spent all of yesterday downloading applications--Origin, Sims 4 game and expansions, Arc, and Photoshop are the big ones--and could still browse the web or do whatever. I haven't upgraded the RAM yet so I was pleasantly surprised that it could manage so much with only 4GB. Played the Sims and ran a Mud at the same time without any issue. I haven't actually used Photoshop yet but when I do, I'll update this review if I run into any problems.

2. Matte screen: A minor pro. I just prefer matte to glossy.

3. Lack of bloatware: I was pleasantly surprised with the number of pre-installed apps on this computer. Almost all memory was free when I booted up the first time. The few games and apps that were already on the computer were uninstalled with a few clicks and that was it.

CONS
1. Touchpad: Two-finger scrolling is my favorite way to scroll, but it's hard to do on this computer. The touchpad is too far to the left (I'm righthanded; if I was lefthanded I'd be happy) and scrolling is way too inconsistent. It will decide to jump across the screen and click on something when I'm just trying to scroll down a page and I feel like I'm assaulting the touchpad because it takes so much pressure. There has to be a way to change this but if there is, it's not under the "Mouse & Touchpad" section of Settings.

2. Size: It's really not fair for me to put this under cons because I knew what I was getting into, but there's just something awkward about this computer. It seems like it should be about an inch or two smaller; there's a disconnect between size and weight that bothers me.

3. No lights: It's impossible to tell if you have CAPS LOCK on because there is no indicator light. I have to just type and figure it out for myself. Obviously not a big deal but still annoying.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
If I run into any problems or find any huge changes once the RAM is upgraded, I'll update this review. For now, I don't regret the purchase. Just hope it can handle Photoshop and Premiere Pro being run.

I purchased this notebook in January after reading CNET reviews on small notebooks.  I just wanted something lightweight that I could take with me to meetings and use Word, Excel and Power Point with, and view videos.  Nothing like gaming or anything elaborate.  It came loaded with Windows 10 Operating system.  The notebook is light and very cheaply made.  After an unsuccessful Windows 10 update I tried to remove the battery and restart the system.  That's when I discovered how difficult it is to just access the battery and the S/N (under the motherboard).  By doing so (I watched a YouTube video to find out how - support is non existent for ASUS) I disconnected the keyboard cable and have never been able to replace it so that the entire keyboard works.  This is such a poorly constructed notebook.  Light yes.  Crap yes.  And support ... well good luck with that.  I ended up buying a wireless keyboard and mouse rather than fight the ongoing battle with ASUS over fixing the system.  Buyer beware.

I spent a lot of time researching which computer I wanted to get prior to my purchase. (I am not a computer/tech buff by any means) but I did take the time to educate myself on the benefits of different processors etc.  This computer had great reviews, was budget friendly, and seemed to meet my requirements.  I have had the computer for a few months now and I definitiely liked my old Toshiba better.  I don't know if I just got a "dud" or if all of these laptops are like this but the mouse pad is EXTREMELY sensitive.  I have gotten used to it but every time my significant other tries to use my computer he goes crazy and always says "I don't know how you put up with this".  It also seems a bit slow.  It takes several minutes before I can connect to the internet when I turn it on or when it wakes from sleep modes.  It also took some time to get used to the on/off key, in the beginning I often accidently hit the key when trying to hit the escape button and the computer would shut off.  Maybe they could add in an extra step to truning the computer off that asks if you are sure so you don't have to boot the whole thing back up because of a simple mistake.  Based on my experience I would probably try a different brand next time I purchase a laptop.

Maybe I'm stretching a little by giving this laptop a five star rating, but I have my reasons:
My wife and I purchased this laptop for my senior citizen mom who lives with us. She's fairly tech-savvy and has been talking about wanting to get more involved online since she recently retired. First, I have a gaming PC by Asus, the verified purchase review is in my review history. I've had zero issues with my Asus. Which leads to the first good thing about this laptop ... there's no bloatware whatsoever on this laptop. Once I had set up the Windows 10 account and MS went through their "we're getting it ready" screens, the laptop screen opened up with only one icon on it ... the recycling bin.

This does mean there's no security software outside of Windows Defender/Security that comes with Windows 10, but I have a Webroot subscription with extra machines left on it. The closest you'll come to bloatware on this laptop is the pre-installed Office software. Unlike previous versions of Windows, it's not as easy to remove those, but in our case, I already had a multi-license use for Office 2016 and entered the product key. It's sort of a good/bad point there since I really don't know how to remove it if you don't have a key. Still, there's nothing on this laptop to pop up and say, "Would you like to play (name) games?" or any unknown, unheard of photo software.

I tested the battery life out while setting it up. I used it for four hours and still had about 1/3rd of the battery left. I'm sure different tasks use up the battery faster, but it's a decent battery for the price of this laptop. The AC Wifi connection is very good. We have an AC router in our kitchen. Going to the far end of the house didn't show any drop in speedtests. Mom loves the Bluetooth 4.0, she has a little Bluetooth speaker in her room. It connected easily. There's two USB 3.0 ports and one USB 2.0 port. There's also an HDMI port.

One thing I especially liked about was the ease of upgrading the RAM. While I honestly believe 4 GB of RAM will be enough for her uses, I still opted to buy 8 GB more thanks to one of the answers in the questions area. I bought this laptop to be a family computer for general purpose use. Writing letters/school papers, surfing, cat videos, light gaming. The price was right, which offset my concerns about only 4GB of ram (easily upgradable) and a slow 5400 rpm hard drive (not too difficult to upgrade).

I followed some recommendations found while googling (turning off bluetooth, updating the wifi driver), but results are still pretty bad. This evening, I finally did some more thorough testing.

- Ethernet works great. Downloaded 2 gb of data, averaging 25-32 Mbps.
- 5G wifi starts downloads at around 25 Mbps, but after a few seconds, drops down to 6-8 Mbps
- 2.5G wifi is useless, starting at around 11 Mbps, but then dropping down to 0.4 Mbs

Downloading the same file on my wife's laptop with 2.4G wifi is almost as fast as ethernet - 25 Mbps. All testing (wired and wifi) were done on the same router.

This is likely to be a lengthy review.

1. Aesthetics:
-The entire body of this laptop is plastic.
-There is an "anti-fingerprint/anti-smudge" texture to the top of the lid which I find tends to trap dust.
-The form factor is pretty slim and the entire machine is nice and light

2. Function
-This computer has a i3 2.1 GHz processor, which is fine for most computing use. However if you are a gamer or someone that codes more than just websites, find a different machine
-There is a full 10-key pad
-The computer utilizes the chicle style keyboard, with the key coming up through the body of the machine
-There is a fair amount of keyboard flex due to the design of the board and the plastic body
-The computer has on-board Intel HD 5500 graphics which will play most videos in HD without bogging down the system
-The HS is not an SSD, although you cannot really hear it spin
- The exhaust for the fan is in an odd location making it hard to clean. It is dead center in the gap for the monitor hinge. Personally I think the actually hinders airflow through the chassis.
-The computer claim to have cool touch but you can feel the warmth to the right of the trackpad under heavy use.
-The hard drive is not actually 500GB as claimed, (this is due to manufactures being allowed to market a GB as 1000MB when it is actually 1024MB meaning this system really only has about 488GB storage.)
-There is only one user serviceable bay on the the bottom of the machine and that is to upgrade the memory, which this machine can only take 8GB
-It has a clickable trackpad which can only be disabled via the BIOS menus, so if you want to use a mouse and not run the risk of random bumps on the trackpad you'll need to access the BIOS setting and disable the internal pointing device
-There is a webcam for video chatting, but the quality isn't that great.
-There are 2 USB 3 port, 1 USB 2.0
-Ethernet port
-Wi-Fi
-Kensington slot (for securing your laptop with a Kensington Cable Lock)
-SD card slot that accepts standard SD cards. A word of Warning the card does not fit fully into the slot and hangs about 2/3 the way out of the machine which could lead to damage to the card or the slot is something is dropped close to the card.
-There is an optical drive, but honestly I have used it 2 times in the year I have owned the machine.

Overall the ASUS F555LA-AB31 is a decent entry level machine. It would be great for doing homework, browsing the net, email, light gaming, social media, and sending with your child to college.

If you're an enthusiast or a power user, this is not the machine for you.

I am a college student, and this laptop has done me good most of the time. It came with windows 8 and was easily upgraded to windows 10. The only issues which may to some can be major, was an issue with a faulty hardrive disk. This was slowly killing my laptop, but the warranty completely took care of that in about a week and a have. And again their is an issue of the speakers stopping and cutting out.

It is a simple laptop that gets the simple jobs done efficiently. If you use complex computer programs then i would advise looking into a better laptop.

I've had this laptop for two weeks, and I'm not disappointed. It does what I want it to do. Good for everyday use, streaming videos, playing some low requirement games like terraria, minecraft, etc. Here are some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Nice and light
- Doesn't get hot
- Easy to upgrade ram with a compartment on the bottom with one screw. Make sure you find the correct compatible ram for this. Any DDR3L ram for laptops won't work.
- Good battery life get around 4-5 hours using it continuously without gaming, 2-3 while gaming.
- Full keyboard (15.6 in laptops I've seen in the past never had one unless I'm just crazy)

Cons:
- Center on the keyboard is not supported very well. Don't press crazy hard on it cause it will feel like you will snap the keyboard in half.
- Touchpad is a little bit of a pain. Doesn't respond well some of the time when clicking and dragging on the screen.
- Dedicated vram from the processor is locked at 32 MB. Need to go into the bios on startup to set it to 512 MB. That was annoying and didn't know that without looking online.
- 4 GB of ram but I knew it when I bought it. Cheap to upgrade to 12 GB with a 8GB stick.

Non of the cons warrant a star removal just annoying but not ever laptop is perfect. Highly recommend when I got it for 350$ at the time. Don't pay more than 400$ for it.

When I plugged it in again to try to charge it the battery continued to indicate from the lights on the side of the laptop that it was not charging and it would not boot up ever again even though it was plugged into the wall.  Returned the machine for a refund.

I have been using the laptop since December of 2015. First, the installed bloatware isn't bad at all. You'll be able to remove most of it in Control Panel.

The keyboard is TERRIBLE. This is the most unresponsive, cheap keyboard I have ever used. In fact, I bought a wired keyboard just to make this laptop usable. Maybe I got a bad keyboard on mine, but it's required to use a wired keyboard in order to type with any speed on this laptop.

Trackpad is alright. Nothing great, but not bad either. Considering the price of this laptop, it's nothing to complain about.

Screen has bad viewing angles and average colors. Sure it's 1080p but looks worse than my old Macbook. Much worse. But it's okay, once again, considering this laptop goes for less than $400. Some of the pixels will go black but a reboot fixes it.

This laptop often has problems connecting to 5ghz networks. Every other computer and device I own has no issue connecting to my wifi, but this laptop often disconnects itself. I have tried multiple router brands, doesn't seem to help. No issues on 2.4ghz networks. Maybe this is just an issue with my laptop..

Feels very plastic-y but that makes it lightweight and easy to hold.

It can play games like CS:GO, minecraft, garry's mod, etc. @30fps or greater on 1080p medium/high settings. Note that the laptop was elevated and had external fans cooling it. Also I am not a "gamer" by any means, so your results will vary. And this isn't a gaming laptop, so you shouldn't expect great results. Let me preface this by saying that while I'm no IT professional, I have an above average handle over general computer maintenance and repair. Hardware is not really my thing, but if I've successfully built a desktop in the past, I shouldn't have problems doing minor hardware repairs. All of that said, this a good laptop with a few major problems.

Pros:

-1080p screen
-i3 processor is powerful enough to handle average use (I previously only owned i5 processors)
-Good keyboard (Some years ago, I owned an ASUS K53E which was nearly impossible to type accurately on)
-Solid construction (My previous laptop was a Lenovo G580, which had a very cheap build quality and which totally fell apart after some time)
-Dual-band WiFi
-Better-than-expected battery life (I'd say it can easily last 4 hours or longer and it charges quickly)
-Touchpad (It's similar to the Mac trackpads that don't actually include separate buttons for left and right click)
-Lightweight and relatively thin
-Great price

Cons:

-Difficult to modify/repair/replace hardware (I'll get into this later)
-WiFi constantly loses connection (I'll get into this later)
-Haven't had success upgrading RAM (Up to this point, I thought it was a product defect, but I now suspect that I've not had success because I've been trying to put a 1.5v chip in, and this laptop takes 1.35v)
-Touchpad (I'll get into this later)
-Windows 7 is not supported (This is probably not a major issue for anyone, but if you want to run Windows 7 on this laptop, you'll have to find drivers from other manufacturers because Asus does not provide them. If you know what you're doing, this shouldn't be a problem, but I'm not positive you'll find a touchpad driver)

Now, onto the two largest issues:

Unless you're an expert, you're going to have a tough time modifying or replacing hardware. Something as simple as replacing the hard drive with a SSD requires removing 10 screws to open the laptop. Except removing those 10 screws won't actually open the laptop because first, you'll have to remove all of the plastic clips keeping it together. For this, you'll need something like an old credit card, a lot of time, and even more patience. The first time probably took me half-an-hour. After the first time, it gets easier, but it's still not easy. Once you manage to get the laptop open and disconnect the keyboard and trackpad cables, you'll need to unscrew and remove a little board that has the card reader, headphone input, and a USB port. Finally, you can unscrew the hard drive cage and replace the HDD with an SSD.

This illustrates the problem. Users are not meant to open this laptop for any reason. The RAM that's included is soldered in. The battery is not removable (unless, perhaps, you're a pro), and in general, it is difficult to access any parts. This takes me to the next major problem I'd like to discuss: WiFi.

When the WiFi works, it works wonderfully. Connected to the 5gz network, I typically get 125mbps DL and 20mbps UL. The problem is, the WiFi card DOESN'T always work as it should. It randomly disconnects, and I have to troubleshoot the connection to get it to work again. This can happen multiple times a day or even multiple times within an hour. I've tried installing driver updates from both Asus and other manufacturers, but none seem to fix the problem. I suspect that the card is bad, and it should be simple to replace cheaply, but I can only imagine how hard it will be to access and remove the wireless card. I may be able to do it myself, but I can't even find instructions online about how to disassemble the laptop past replacing the hard drive. I may tinker with it a bit and see what I can do, but I'm not hopeful. Given how much I rely on my laptop, I can't imagine parting with it for weeks for Asus to repair it under warranty, so I'll probably have to take it to a shop (something that someone with my IT skills shouldn't ordinarily have to do) in order to get it replaced, and I'll probably have to pay an exorbitant amount of money to do so.

One other (more minor) problem:

The included touchpad software offers no way to assign the middle mouse button click to a gesture. The previous two laptops I've owned allowed the user to assign a two-finger or three-finger tap to middle click, which I use extensively to open new browser tabs, to close tabs, and to scroll up and down webpages. Often times, even when the manufacturer's software doesn't include the options, various registry settings can be tweaked in order to allow this functionality. As far as I can tell, even that cannot be done with this laptop. The only solution I've found is a freeware program someone much more knowledgeable than myself wrote in order to rectify the problem on his own laptop. The solution basically hijacks the command that would ordinarily happen when tapping three fingers (ordinarily, it would open Cortana), and instead, sends the middle mouse button click. This software has made the computer usable, but it's got some major inconveniences. The first is that it only works about 85% of the time. At seemingly random times and frequencies, Cortana will still open up. This gets annoying pretty quickly. The other issue is that it does not work when controlling another computer using Remote Desktop Connection, which is something I do all the time. Frustrating.

Anyway, it's a good computer, but if you're considering buying it, just hope that you never have to repair or replace any hardware. Otherwise, you're in deep trouble.

I originally bought this as a light-use travel computer, as part of replacing my old clunky laptop with a high-powered desktop and a cheapo notebook for the relatively rare occasions I need to travel.  But I like it so much I don't feel the need to get the desktop.  I replaced the hard drive with an SSD and it blazes, even without a memory boost (might do that later).  This is really a necessary thing, because for some reason the hard drive gets quite hot under the palm rest.  Without that, the computer itself never does, and in fact it's virtually silent, another big plus.  Replacing the hard drive is a little nerve-wracking, but ultimately not that difficult.  The youtube video shows you how to open the case with a plastic card like a credit card.  It runs Photoshop and Google Earth just fine; the speakers sound tinny on the default settings, but tweak it just a little and even they sound decent.

Another advantage of putting in an SSD is that it seems to extend the battery life.  People have said the regular battery life is 3-5 hours, but I get 7+ hours easily.  This is my first time having a laptop with a real usable battery (all my earlier ones claimed 4-5 hours and usually got 2 hour of the box, dropping to 1.5 after a year or so), and I'm loving it.

The screen is very bright, a nice difference from most of the other cheap laptops that have very dim screens even on full brightness.  It's so bright I have to turn it down a bit so the whites don't hurt my eyes when I'm indoors!  It's also great that it has an ethernet port and CD drive, rare items on computers this small and light, let alone at this price point.  It does seem odd though that they crammed in a VGA port as the external display, instead of going with the much smaller DisplayPort or HDMI.

The one thing I have issues with is the keyboard.  I actually liked it better at first, because the keys are closer together than on all the others I tried (HP, Acer, Lenovo, Dell), so it fits better with my hands.  But for some reason I keep missing letters when I'm typing (that is, I hit the key but no letter shows up).  I think it's due to not hitting straight down or with enough force, as I'm not used to using any of these chiclet-style keyboards (even my previous laptop had a long-travel keyboard).  It's not super strongly built - you can't expect that for under $350 - but it only flexes a little in the keyboard and on the bottom near the CD drive door, otherwise it's fairly solid.

All things considered, the cons are pretty minor.  This is a great computer!

My sister bought this laptop a few weeks ago for me so that I can use it to work from home and I must say that so far it has met and sometimes exceeded my expectations.

The specs that you get for the price are second to none and the performance is awesome for working from home and everyday use. Don't expect to play games like The witcher 3 on this though because that's just not gonna happen. This is a computer for everyday use and for the price it under promises and over delivers.

It comes with an intel core i3 5010u 2.1GHz processor, dvd-rw drive, windows 10, 4GB of ram which can be upgraded to up to 12GB of RAM, (Mine currently has 4GB RAM but I am now waiting for my 8GB RAM stick to arrive so I can throw it in their and start churning performance out of this "kitten") It also comes with a 500 GB 5400 hard drive which I will be repalcing with a Samsung internal 1TB SSD and using as an external Hard drive, Wifi ac which is up to 3 times as fast as normal wifi, 1080p monitor (TN Panel) and HDMI port, 2 USB 3.0 ports and a USB 2.0 port as well as a VGA port. It also sports a 3.5mm headphone jack and a media card reader standard and finally my favorite feature: IceCool Technology.... Rest your palms on this badboy all day if you like and it won't hold it against you and get super toasty making it uncomfortable for you to use your pc for extended periods. It performs like  a champ when it comes to keeping cool and so far I am very happy with it.

Pros:1080p resolution, wifi ac, usb 3.0 ports, vga compatible, IceCool Technology*, lightweight, good battery life overall, great sound quality, League of Legends plays flawlessly at max settings..., super fast charging, great price, the list could go on for a while....

Cons: The monitor though it has 1080p resolution seems to be a TN panel so you have to be looking straight at it to get a clear picture but hey you get what you pay for and at $340... This bad boy is hard to beat. There is nothing else I can think of except that I haven't gotten my 12GB RAM and my SSD yet.... (Those are things I will be changing soon anyways).

Conclusion: I would recommend  it to anyone who wants a great pc at a great price for everyday use. I hope this review makes Asus and Amazon a lot of money and helps make a lot of happy and satisfied customers xD.

I use my laptop computer everyday, for hours at a time.  My last computer died unexpectedly and I didn't have a lot of money to spend on a new one. No matter what I do, I can't get the vivid colors I got from my last computer, and 2) the keyboard has a cheap feel to it.  The number pad is especially bad; the whole area "sinks" when you press on one number.  There are other issues that are more related to Windows 10 and I can't blame Asus for these problems. And the first thing I did was yank the 5400RPM garbage drive out of it and slap in a Samsung 850 EVO 500gb SSD and install Windows 10 fresh.  RAM at 4gb is a little light for the use case I have in mind, so I'll likely get another 4gb module for it, but even before that the unit cranks up in 4 seconds and everything launches at a click.
