This is an okay computer. I bought it because of the screen. I'm a grad-student and spend a lot of time writing, and watching youtube videos when I should be writing, so I have come to appreciate crisp resolution. The Full HD resolution on this Asus hits the spot. The 1080p is noticeable right off the bat (not only because all of the icons and print are smaller), and I have not had any eye pains or headaches like I used to get after a couple hours on my 2013 Toshiba satellite. However the viewing angles are far worse compared to my old laptop, and the screen brightness is kind of a bummer. For example I'm in a naturally lit room on full brightness and the background whites still have a bluish hue. Also the bezel is huge, especially at the top, making this the biggest, albeit lightest 15.6 laptop I've ever had. (I always get 15.6 inch screens because I like having two tabs open on either side of the screen, unfortunately the screen is not as wide as my last computer, and the dual windows are a little narrow for my liking).
The computer is also a little sluggish for what I was expecting, definitely slower than my last computer when it was fresh out of the box. They have the same specs, both 4gb of ram, Intel core 3 (of course the Toshiba was 3rd gen I believe), and a big ol' harddrive. Maybe it's windows 10 that requires more ram, slowing this Asus down, or maybe it was the Geek Squad that tuned my old computer up just right...I don't know, but my 2013 toshiba was faster (before the windows 10 upgrade).
The keyboard also leaves something to be desired. The keys are squeky and the keyboard is the only part of the computer that really feels cheap. There is no capslock light anywhere on the keyboard, and there is no way to lock the function keys. Finally, the keyboard appears cramped with an unused 3/4" space on both sides.
The track pad works fine for a trackpad, it is big, but manages to stay out of the way while typing.
The battery lasts about 4-5 hours of average work. I figure this will decrease with time, but  I don't move around too much so it's no problem.
All in all, if you need to have a 15.6 inch computer and are tired of staring at 720p this is the way to go. If you don't spend a lot of time on your computer, however, you might want to look into getting more ram or an SSD to speed things up. I heard asus motherboards are the best around, but this laptop just lacks spunk.
I'm moving in a couple weeks and will be taking the ram out of my old computer to put in here, from what I've read that gives this computer the edge it needs. I may look into the SSD later on as well.

It's a pretty darn good laptop for the money.

Build quality is pretty good. Doesn't feel overly flimsy or weak at any point. Keyboard is responsive as well, and the touchpad is decent enough.

The screen, which is probably why most of you are looking at this laptop.... well, it IS a 1080p screen. You can't really find a laptop in this pricepoint that had a 1080p screen, so good on Asus for making this affordable.

Why do I sound hesitant? It's a 1080p screen, but it's a TN panel. And a very, very bad TN panel at that. Any amount of angle to your viewing and blacks become so washed out they're basically white. Contrast is also quite horrible viewing from the front as well. I've tried attempting to fix it by calibrating the display but it doesn't seem to be fixable, rather just inherent to the lower quality display.

Other than the screen problems, it's a solid buy. It is a little difficult to get apart to change out the hard drive (get an SSD for this, it makes it 100% faster. They're using a 5400 RPM hard disk in this so it's slow.)

There are videos out there detailing how to take similar models apart, so just follow those if you want.

Nice laptop for the price. Seems to perform well during the short time in use.
HOWEVER, after about 8 hours of use and after getting most of Win10 set up and applications loaded, the screen colors went bad. Everything had a very greenish tint. Contacted ASUS support and received very good response - quick confirmation of the problem and issuance of a RMA for repair including a shipping label via FedEx Ground. Repair time was stated as being a three day turn-around after receipt. This was accomplished and about a week later the laptop was returned with a note of LCD replacement. Turned it on and was very disappointed to see that the problem had NOT been corrected. The software configuration was untouched so that was a plus. Another call to the support folks. First time call got routed to never-land, return call was good. Once again a RMA was issued but I had to specifically ask for a return shipping label (rep said they usually only supply one for the first incident - does that mean if it fails again during the one year warranty they expect you to cover the shipping?) They did cover it this time since it was a repeat problem. Received the laptop back a week later. Only note was that there was an "error message". Looks like whatever was done fixed the problem this time. This time the hard disk had apparently been replaced because all my Win10 setup and applications/data were gone. So a good couple of weeks of unavailability and redo. Hopefully that was an isolated incident.

Have noted that when using the system for presentations using an external large screen TV monitor the colors are somewhat over-saturated. I have not been able to immediately resolve this but it might be better with a bit of tweaking. Need more experimenting time with this.

Another minor issue is that there is no keyboard or status light(s) to indicate when Caps Lock or Num Lock is turned on. All that would take is a small LED embedded in the key(s).

This laptop is among Amazon's top 5 selling laptops, and it's easy to see why. Frankly, if price is one of your biggest concerns, but you still want a laptop that won't have any problem doing web browsing, word processing, photo management and editing, Skype, etc., this is a good choice. The price is very reasonable, and the specs are fairly up to date. There are newer processors and laptops with more memory, but this is still a good choice. I actually would recommend purchasing some more memory (like maybe this Kingston Memory) and putting it in, which is very easy. There's a panel on the bottom held in place with a single screw. Open it up, line up the memory, put it in at an angle, then push it down flat. With upgraded memory, this laptop will be an excellent daily driver. The 1080p screen is a nice bonus.

I have had this computer for several months now. I really wanted to get used to it and test it out before reviewing it. I spent a lot of time saving and researching before deciding on the F Series Asus laptop. And, overall it has lived up to my expectations. It is a great size for watching video/movies on and the DVD drive is a definite plus with great playback. The sound is decent & crisp, but if there is a lot of background noise, I prefer using my headphones for better volume. I got mine with Windows 10. Took me a bit of getting used to, but overall I like it. I did end up creating folders on my desktop for my photos and videos as it was taking forever to try and arrange them on this set up. And, I am a bit bummed that I can't save to my One Drive cloud without having it take up space on my laptop as well, but there are plenty of other cloud services, so this wasn't too big of an issue for me. I am a multi-tasker and often running 3 - 5 windows at a time including video and have been very please with how well the laptop keeps up with me. The speed is great until the battery gets low. Once you are just above 10%, it slows down dramatically and at 7%...well...it's not really 7%, it is time to plug in. lol But, I can do my multi-tasking and still get a good 3 - 4 hours on the battery. When I first got it, the built in mousepad and keyboard were the one thing I didn't care for. The mousepad takes up nearly half of the space and was a bit sensitive. However, you can adjust how the mousepad works or even have it disabled when using a wired/wireless mouse. I have adjusted to the set up now and barely notice. So, are there some little things that may bother people? Sure. But, what you get for the asking price on this is amazing and I am so happy with this purchase and look forward to using this laptop for a good long time.

PROS:
1080p screen - great for enjoying the best video resolution that is widely available (such as through Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon)
i3 processor - the go to processing power for moderate usage (not so high that it'd bump the price by $100-$200) you can stream videos while browsing the web and typing a paper without having the pc slow down
2 USB 3.0 ports - really fast transfer speeds; you can generally get between 70 to 150 megabytes per second depending on the usb 3.0 flash drive and how large the files are/how many there are.
HDMI and VGA port - HDMI is becoming a standard, and VGA means that it can be connected to a projector.

CONS:
Battery - it is built into the laptop, so you cannot remove it if you're having issues with the pc and want to have the computer do a reboot from no power; you also cannot remove it if it is defective, loses charge, or simply want to use another battery.
Hard Drive Bay - Usually the bay is located on the bottom of the laptop and can be replaced by unscrewing the panels the cover it; with this laptop, you have to remove the keyboard frame to access the hard drive bay. This, of course, is only a downer if you were planning to use an ssd with the laptop and not risk damaging it.

I gave this two starts because the laptop it's self isn't bad...decent specs and not bad build quality. However, holy hell, the trackpad is awesomely bad. Go google the trackpad problems with this machine and you'll immediately get about 20 hits for people complaining about it.

I'm fairly computer savvy overall and thought I could fix this via driver switching or rolling back versions of Asus Smart gesture...I was wrong...this simply isn't a software issue, it's just a VERY cheap trackpad.

To give you an example of how bad this is, every time you right click to go to context, and then left click to select something your mouse will jump about 50 px, which of course makes you select the wrong option. Now imagine trying to do two or three finger gestures. (Pinch to Zoom and Rotate is straight out).

Asus usually makes decent stuff, but pass on this machine, it's awful.

I cannot believe how great this notebook is for $339!!!  My old HP notebook was dying and over the last few months I had spent hours reviewing other placements at budget prices as that is all I can afford.  However, nothing really seemed to fit the bill.  Then the HP notebook took another nosedive so one night, I just took to Amazon and this was the first notebook to appear.  I quickly read a couple of reviews, saw the number of stars and reviewers and just ordered it before I changed my mind.  Afterwards, I was concerned about having buyers' remorse (as I did with the HP), but I'd been looking for a while.  In the morning, I spent more time looking at reviews for this and nobody but the persnickety were saying anything bad.

It has arrived and I am delighted with it.  I cannot believe I got this for $339.  The mouse track is great, very much like Apple's, the display is phenomenal (full HD), I do see what one reviewer said about the keyboard being a little bouncy (I can live with that esp. after HP which had a keyboard that jumped on the screen on you), love the DVD read/write, HDMI port, and speakers.  Again, can't believe what I've got for $339.  I am upgrading the RAM (no brainer) and will replace the hard drive with an SSD when the warranty runs out as that performance improvement is noticeable even by someone like me who is not measuring performance by the nanoseconds.  Now I hope this computer can go the distance (i.e. everything still works at the end of 2 years).

I bought it about one month ago.  So far so good. It seems working well except one strange thing: the windows system is going to expire by the end of this month. I totally do not understand.  Here is the screen shot.  For this reason, I give it 3 starts.
I am still getting used to the computer but so far I am quite pleased.  Everything is much faster compared to my old computer.

This computer is a tremendous value for the money, if you understand your own usage demands.  I am a professor, business owner, and a student.  I spend quite a bit of time using Microsoft Office, Quickbooks, Blackboard, grading papers, writing papers, performing internet research, creating lecture videos, posting content, and communicating with overseas clients on video conferencing and webinars.  I usually have ALL of these programs open at one time.  This computer is more than enough for any and all of those tasks.  I also watch TV on the computer and training videos, from time to time.  If you are a gamer, perform high-end design or graphic functions, or require large amounts of operating memory to get through your day, this computer may NOT be for you.  All I can say, is that I work it hard all day, everyday, and it is terrific.

I also owned its predecessor of the same model and I will admit that the construction is quite a bit "cheaper" feeling than the one I bought before.  My original unit was more sturdy and of significant weight.  This unit is much lighter, but also uses cheaper materials in construction.  Well, listen, if you want a cheaper/lighter unit, then you have to expect cheaper/lighter materials.  My old unit is still going strong after 4 years.  This unit stays at my office and is my primary computer while I am there!  I am also thinking about replacing my employee's computers with this laptop, as well.

Know thyself and check the specifications to match them with your usage patterns and you should be fine purchasing this unit!

As was noted in other reviews, this laptop lives up to its low price and not much more. The keyboard, especially, feels thin and plasticky, as well as the surrounding area. Yes, I know it's plastic, but it feels cheap and hollow to the touch. Also, the keys themselves seem larger than most other boards I've used - larger means the keys are also farther apart which, if you're used to typing fast, is a bit of a learning curve adjustment.

The one other negative observation is that the touch pad is, well, not great. They've made a decent effort to match the touch and gestures in Mac products, but it's just not there yet. For instance, when sliding two fingers up or down (to scroll), the monitor image often expands as if I were spreading my fingers diagonally to accomplish that task. I've tried it every which-way with my fingers, but it still happens. I'm hoping to find some settings adjustments to stop this from happening, as it's very annoying. The outer plastic has a rather odd radial texture to it. Again, feels cheap and hollow. Monitor screen is nice; the computer itself is fast enough. (I did add 8GB of memory to it, though.)

I do feel it's worth the price. Since I'm intending to use it only for the rare Windows task (I've now converted completely over to Apple/Mac) it should fill my needs adequately.

The only reason I haven't given it five stars is that the touchpad is a little "floaty"-feeling, and the case feels a little cheap, though it's actually surprisingly sturdy. There's also a bit of keyboard bounce, though nothing seriously annoying.

Now, the good parts: the Broadwell Core i3-5010U CPU is amazingly zippy for something that's sold as middle of the road at best, and very efficient. It doesn't turbo, but its base clock is plenty and it does more in its 15-watt TDP than equivalently-clocked Sandybridge and Ivybridge (i3-2xxxM and 3xxxM) CPUs do in 35W, not to mention its graphics are better. Intel's really nailed its process architecture; Broadwell may only be a 14nm Haswell shrink, but it does everything right.

The screen. Ohhhhh mercy, the screen. Full HD at this price point is unheard of. Yes, it's a TN panel with narrow viewing angles, it's a bit pale and washed-out, and it doesn't have very high contrast. But it's good enough, and the difference 1920x1080 makes over 1366x768 is like night and day. Asus deserves major, major praise for this and I hope they continue the trend of putting better-than-1366 panels in budget models. The screen is my main draw to this model, and the main reason I recommend it to clients and customers.

The keyboard is a bit better than expected at this price point. For a budget machine, it feels good, if a little bit unstable. There's some flex if you hit the keys hard like I do; it's not a Thinkpad. But it's good enough even for long typing sessions, and Asus is the only company that still makes more or less full-height arrow keys. The touchpad, again, feels a bit floaty and spacey, but nothing majorly wrong.

Maintenance: thre's no maintenance hatch, which is becoming more and more common these days, sadly. Luckily, it's not *too* horribly difficult to maintain: undo all the bottom panel screws and carefully prise the panel up with a spudger or other thin plastic tool. Don't yank it up; the keyboard is ribbon-cable'd to the bottom and needs to be released. Once done, you can access the hard drive bay easily. I *highly* recommend replacing the HDD with an SSD, which is what I do for all my customers; this machine absolutely screams with an SSD.

OS: Windows is Windows. My opinions on Windows are not printable in polite company, so I will leave it at that, with a side note commending Asus for keeping its bloatware levels down, especially compared to HP and Lenovo. This machine also takes Linux like a champ, and I have had success running Arch with XFCE and some heavy tweaks to make it look like a Mac. This is where the FHD screen shines; combine this machine with an SSD and Linux, and you can make something massively faster and more pleasant to use than the price would seem to indicate.

Overall, this is an excellent machine with a few flaws that are entirely forgivable at this price. It's an extremely well-balanced package and offers amazing value for the money, plus if you know what you're doing you can get the kind of experience that normally costs twice as much out of it. Bravo, Asus; this is yet another reason you're my favorite!
Good for the price
Using for online graduate school and is great for what I need.  The battery life seems to be forever!  It is quick and fun.  I wish the keyboard lit up, but that is the only downside as of now.

General Remarks #1: Laptops at this price point are ample if your needs are web surfing, watching DVD movies, using Word and Excel and so on.  Look at a higher price point if your interests include high-end gaming, high-end graphics design, or voluminous video editing.

General Remarks #2: I paid $369.99 for this PC, and in trailing remarks I compare this laptop to others I've considered within the $350-$400 range.  For now I regard this laptop as an excellent buy at this price range.  The future is anyone's guess.

Pluses
* High definition 1920x1280 screen, uncommon at this price point.  Very sharp screen.
* Remarkably good assortment of native ports (so no adapter needed): HDMI, VGA, RJ45 for Ethernet, memory card reader
* Two USB3 ports (not just one) plus one USB2 port
* Very easy memory upgrade (not that memory upgrade is difficult anyway but on this laptop it is super-easy).  I paid an additional $25 for an 8GM memory chip to upgrade memory from 4GB to 12GB.

Neutral
* The laptop includes features expected for this price range: 500GB hard drive, 5th generation Intel I3 processor, 4GM memory, DVD player, 80211c WIFI.

Minuses
* Screen is not easily readable at an angle.  So two people watching a movie should be friends and three would soooooo need to be budsies.

Overall
* Excellent buy at this price point.  It is a smart choice for most of what most people want to do most of the time on a laptop.

Subjective Remarks
* I purchased this laptop for my son who is about to begin as a college freshman.  I anticipate that it will serve him well thru college.
* I like the feel of this keyboard better than the keyboard feel of my own Dell laptop.
* Color is silver on black.  Black on black is more common and I prefer that, but only slightly, and you may see it differently.

I had assumed this would be a decent laptop for regular desktop work, web browsing, and some minimal gaming. But for such a seemingly simple premise, it certainly had its issues.

The start up time for windows ever so slightely became longer each time, and while I do not know if it was due to software or hardware, I did my best to keep everything protected and up to date. I can say for sure that this computer has a decent amount of "bloatware" from asus that you may wish to uninstall.

The intel video card is unimpressive evem for a budget laptop, and struggles to play low intensity games; for example I played Age of Decadence on mostly low settings/resolution in order to have an acceptable fps. The onboard sound card also had problems, especially when multiple sounds had to be processed and played at the same time.

The grande finale of this laptop's short lifespan was the hard disk, which did not seat well and consistently ran at nearly 100% capacity until it broke entirely. This happened in the span of 3-5 days, and I had the computer for only three months total. Some say this is a windows 10 issue, and while i did try a whole array of fixes to prevent it, I could say its a combination of driver issues specific to this computer and windows 10.

Yes, this is a longwinded two star review, but all in all I really do wish for you to at least spend an extra hundred dollars or two on a more mainstream brand with a decent graphics processor. Or if you're looking for pure web browsing and word processing, spend your money on a netbook or some such. This Asus tries to straddle the awkward line of mainstream laptops and budget notebooks and ends up doing nothing well.

There is nothing great about the HD screen.  And I made the mistake of not trying the CD burner in the first 30 days.  It first burned a CD but then I got an error saying it had a problem.  When I put it back in to play the CD it took several tries for it to recognize there was a CD inserted.  It then showed the list of songs but it would not play anything.  Same thing happened on the second try. That is when I went to look at the 1 year warranty info and saw that you have to send it to New Zealand for repairs. I would not recommend purchasing this laptop.

My only fix was slightly brightening up the Red hue to give everything a warmer tone, but even that doesn't bring it up to the basic standards of what i'm use to.

This machine can be used in more ways than just "simple everyday applications" the companies advertise this computer to do. I'm a gamer, and I wanted to run a selection of games on this laptop. Of course, I know that this machine could not run the latest and greatest games, or even the games before that. I have a gaming rig for that, but I needed this laptop to play more casual games. I'll list a few of the games I've tested. Note that I've upgraded the RAM to 8 gb because 4 will just not cut it these days. I have also upped the dedicated video RAM to 512 mb in the BIOS.

Portal/TeamFortress2/Garry'sMod - This laptop will run any source game very fluently on high settings with anti aliasing turned off. Resolution can be turned down to 1600x900 for better performance.

Counter Strike: Global Offensive - Again, game runs nicely on medium/high settings. Again, playing on 1600x900 resolution.

Warframe - Has a bit of trouble with this game. 30-50 fps with low settings and at 1368x768 resolution with most settings turned off.

Minecraft - Runs a clean 40-60 on high settings, although render distance has been turned down a bit to avoid studdering from loading chunks.

Terraria - Runs perfect 60+ fps on 1920x1080 on highest settings.

League of Legends - Runs 80 fps on medium/high settings at 1920x1080. Very fluent.

Those are some of the games I tested and played around with. Overall this laptop is a great buy, good design, great price, great screen, and decent performance. The only gripe I have with this machine is the display colors, which slightly muddles up gloomy and dark colors, while bright and vibrant colors are saturated.

My last laptop was an ASUS and it lasted 8 years, so I went with this product out of brand loyalty as well asn being impressed with some of the features at this price. I purchased it to be a portable workhorse for mostly professional use (I'm a university prof). I've had it about a week and it has exceeded my expectations.
PROS:
Wide HD screen at a really decent price
Numeric keypad is a godsend for folks like me who use spreadsheets every day
Easily expanded it to 12GB of RAM (many thanks to the awesome reviewers who recommended this and even posted videos about how to do it)
With the extra RAM, the laptop effortlessly handles intense data analysis (I run multivariate stats and permutation-based analyses that require RAM). It also handles big files in Illustrator well. In this regard the laptop has exceeded my expectations.
Wifi DL rates are super
Runs very cool
Lightweight, portable
3 USB, 1 SD, VGA and HDMI outputs
Arrived with absolutely zero bloat. Clean slate. Fantastic
Overall, surprisingly high end features for a laptop at this price point.

CONS (none of which I consider major)
Video card simply cannot handle intensive work- for example, it can't handle the live feed from the 10MP microscope camera in my lab, not even close. I haven't even bothered to try gaming on it. To be clear: at this price point, I was expecting this. Just putting this here so potential buyers are fully aware.
The keyboard that comes with this chassis is a bit weird- the keys are densely packed and are quite high off the keyboard, so I find myself often hitting the wrong keys- many typos. But I'm getting used to it. The only key placement I can't really get past is that the right arrow key is displaced to the right and sandwiched between the 1 and 0 on the numerical keypad, which means I am constantly deleting 1's and 0's when editing documents. The arrow keys also feel very small (maybe my fingers are too fat?).
The laptop is light, but this translates to a build that feels somewhat flimsy- the screen flexes alarmingly unless you open/close it by pressing/lifting it from exactly in the middle, for example. I wouldn't put this chassis through the same take-it-anywhere hell I put my ASUS N81, which was bulletproof.

All in all, I am very satisfied with this product after a week or so of intensive use.

I left my job as of March 2016 and needed a personal laptop in order to help me find a new job. After looking around and realizing I really didn't need that much (today's PCs have more power than most normal tasks really ever use and this one is no exception) I settled on the Asus F555L from Amazon. As always it arrived promptly in in great condition. I know from experience that 4 GB of RAM is a bit anemic for me (but probably fine for most light tasks like web browsing, email, office tasks, etc.) so I picked-up an 8 GB memory module at the same time. Installing the memory was a breeze and only required the removal of one screw (and a sticker over that screw). Anyone with basic mechanical aptitude shoul dbe able to upgrade the RAM in this laptop. I had every intention of replacing the hard disk with an SSD but I have yet to do so. Honestly I barely notice the slower spindle-based disk though I will get around to doing this one day in the future--it just hasn't been that important to me yet. Unfortunately replacing the hard disk is not as easy as adding RAM and while it doesn't seem too difficult I wouldn't proceed if this is the first time you've ever attempted such a feat. It's certainly doable for a beginner with moderate technical aptitude but will require the removal of around 10+ screws and unplugging (and re-seating) a small ribbon cable inside the guts of the machine. There are videos on YouTube that show this process and I Recommend watching one of these before attempting the upgrade regardless of skill level. It's been over a month since I acquired the laptop and I use it everyday. It has easily been able to handle 4 small VMs running under Oracle's Virtualbox with not performance degradation noticed. I'm very happy with the purchase and would gladly recommend this to anyone seeking a budget-friendly but still competent laptop. I do recommend the memory upgrade as the module is only around $30 and takes less than 5 minutes to install. Odds are the memory, while not strictly needed, will be required at some point and should help extend the happiness factor of this purchase over the longer term. This is the memory I purchased and installed: Crucial 8GB Single DDR3 1866 MT/s (PC3-14900) SODIMM 204-Pin Memory - CT102464BF186D

Pros-
A battery lasting many hours (but if you want something that will last the entire day, find something else).
No overheating, at least not that I've seen.
A large 1080p screen, which is hard to find at this price point. For me the text size in the Windows settings was set at 125% by default, so if text seems abnormally large or blurry, check that setting.
Decent build quality, with no major faults.

There are only a few minor annoyances-
Comes bundled with ASUS bloatware, but is easily removed.
If you ever fiddle with the keyboard keys like I do, they can be hard to put back in place if taken out.

This is the best in its price range, but of course this price range will not give you the best quality hardware. Its 5400 RPM hard drive and 4 gigabytes of RAM will bottleneck the system, but the hard drive can be replaced with a much faster SSD and there is a slot for adding RAM.

First of all, I must credit Amazon. Every product that I have bought so far works perfectly. I have gotten an RC truck, RC drone, and now this! In fact, I'm writing this review with this amazing laptop. Also, at least for me, shipping is great. All of my products have come about a day early of when they say. If there was one store on Earth, I would hope it would be Amazon!!

Now, back to the laptop. This machine is very fast. The 4GB RAM lets it loads pages very quickly if you're surfing the internet of if you're doing homework. I've had this for a few months now, and it hasn't failed me once yet! The 500GB storage is helpful for storing a file of any size.

The webcam on this performs exceptionally well, as does the sound system. Gaming works well on this, though I haven't tried very many.

Windows 10 is very easy to get used to. I can navigate it easily, and the laptop boots up in less than a minute, so I can get on it quickly.

When opening it from delivery, you will have to charge it for 3 hours before use. The battery can last up to about 8 hours if you're just surfing the internet. This laptop does not heat up at all and the fan is barely audible. It does have a disc drive, a webcam, and three USB ports (2 third generations and 1 second generation). It comes with a charger and battery, though the battery is hard to remove (I don't see why anyone would want to though). The one and only downside is that the keyboard does not light up for night use.

This laptop is an amazing score for me and I hope to use it for years to come. PLEASE BUY!!!!

I just purchased this laptop from Amazon Fulfillment center.  I absolutely love this laptop.  Like many others have stated on here, you can't beat the price of this laptop for a Full HD screen.  I am into technology and I even got the Dell laptop from Best Buy for $299.99 on sale but it has a 1366 x 768 screen resolution.  The 1920 x 1080 is way better and the way to go.  You can't beat the price of this laptop to get full HD.  I also upgraded the RAM to 12GB.  The RAM I chose was http://www.amazon.com/Crucial-PC3-12800-204-Pin-Notebook-CT102464BF160B/dp/B006YG8X9Y?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00.  It is very easy to install this RAM.  There is a slot on the bottom of the laptop.  It has a sticker over the actual screen so you have to peel the sticker off then it will expose the screw.  Simply unscrew the screw, and pull on the tab.  Then insert the RAM at a 45 degree angle and push down and it will snap into place.  I also upgraded the hard drive to a Samsung 250GB SSD (http://www.amazon.com/Samsung-2-5-Inch-Internal-MZ-75E250B-AM/dp/B00OAJ412U?ie=UTF8&keywords=samsung%20ssd&qid=1461283530&ref_=sr_1_2&s=pc&sr=1-2).  This was a little more challenging than other laptops.  You actually have to take all of the screws out on the bottom (please keep them in order because there are 4 different sizes of screws).  Once you have all the screws out, take a credit card around the seam to prop it open.  Then you will need to disconnect a couple of connections.  There is a really good YouTube video.  Just type Asus F555 hard drive and it will come up.  This laptop is running flawlessly and is so quick.  You can't beat having this good of a laptop for the price (less than $500) with a full HD screen!  I highly recommend it.  I don't know why so many people have given bad reviews on this laptop.  I'm a Packaging Engineer and understand that during manufacturing, you can't have 100% quality so some units just may have been duds.  I love this laptop.  The only complaint I can come up with is I wish it had a backlit keyboard.  I know it is cheap, but I think backlit keyboards should come as a standard, but I'll live.

This is a great school laptop. If your not going to be doing anything super intensive this laptop will work for most middle school and high school student. We bought this for our daughter who is in middle school. She uses it for writing papers and researching on the Internet.

If you're a serious gamer, if you do extensive video or photo editing or if you just got to have the latest and greatest then move on. This laptop is not for you.  But if you want a great laptop at a great price.  This is for you.

I've had the Asus F555L for a week now.  I installed Office 2016, Vuepro, FireFox and Chrome.  I haven't tried to stress it out but the laptop has no problems with any of these.  My main reason for getting it was to VPN/RDP for work.  I had trouble getting the RDP to connect but that was about W10 and had nothing to do with the Asus.  I'm also using it for email and casual surfing when I'm sitting in front of the TV instead of firing up my main system in the home office.  The laptop is lightweight and hasn't overheated yet, even when I'm playing my game.

Even though it doesn't meet the minimum hardware requirements I installed Elder Scroll Online Tamriel.  My game is significantly slower starting up then on my desktop but it does run at medium settings with almost no slow down and no obvious problems.  The FPS has dropped to about 12-16 in Solo instances and I haven't been on a major dungeon yet. But I wouldn't do that on this small 15 inch screen anyway when I can do it on my 36 inch gaming system.

Drawbacks (not fails or cons really, more like personal preferences):
-  I did not notice in description that the keyboard is not backlit.  For me this is major disappointment since half the time I use the laptop I'm in a dark room.  The keyboard is completely obscured, I can't type without a light nearby.  I may actually send the laptop back for this reason.
-  Other reviews mentioned the keyboard flexes and bends.  It does.  Doesn't bother me enough to return the Asus, but it makes it feel "sub-premium".
-  Again the keyboard.  The placement of some keys seem illogical; the right arrow key is part of the number pad, the Home and End keys are separated and placed at the farthest, top right corner when they could easily have been placed closer to regular location; the Insert key is on the zero key!! and needs a Fn to work, totally useless and messes me up; a few other oddities.
-  Other reviews mentioned the screen brightness is not great.  True.  And you have to be looking directly at the screen and it has to be tilted just right to get best clarity.

Despite the drawbacks I recommend this laptop (for anyone who will use it in a well lit space)  ;-)

For the money, and the on paper specs, it is 5 stars. I give it 4 stars because they have had to compromise in every aspect to make this product at this price point. A low viewing angle screen, but looks fine (not great, but nothing wrong with it) when you are right in front of it. The keyboard is spongy, not the best, but serviceable. The trackpad works well, and is one of the better things about this unit. It tracks well, and is responsive. Battery life is pretty good. Lastly, it has a Blu-ray drive, which I missed in the specs when I ordered it. A nice touch, it works well. Finally, this laptop came with the least amount of pre-installed crapware I have yet seen on a laptop, considering that means I have to spend less time despamming it than I would with another computer.

For browsing the web, watching movies, and having a modern O/S, this is a fantastic value. Well done Asus. Dollar for dollar, this is a tough machine to beat. If you want to do any serious tasks like video editing, heavy photo-shopping, 3d games, this is not your machine. If you only want to browse, watch movies, and do word processing or emails, (sparingly, the KB is not good enough to write a long thesis or report on), it will do the job well enough. Don't buy more than what you need. For the value, this machine is 5/5. Overall, 4.5 stars.

I'm very happy with this laptop. This is top of the line for its price range. The screen is a high res screen with crystal clear graphics. I haven't noticed the problem with mine of viewing it from an angle. It seems viewable from all angles. VT-x/d is enabled by default in the BIOS so running operating systems in a Virtual Box is blazing fast. I did add an extra 8Gigs of RAM. The 802.11ac adapter gives me better signal strength than my Atheros b/g/n adapter did, as advertised.

The only con I can see is that the keyboard and bezel has to be removed to replace the hard drive. I've only had this laptop for about a week so I'm just waiting to make sure all is OK before I do.

I would recommend this for anyone needed a non gaming productivity laptop to replace an older model that is too slow for new hardware or has just died....

I read the gray screen problema and i thought it wouldnt happen to me But when it arrived i got a dammm gray screen.

For the price its a good option.  I bought this for my wife to use for website editing and general use.  She is not a "power user" by any means.  I also bought a 128 gb SSD and installed it from the very beginning.  As an IT professional I have to say replacing the HDD was rather difficult.  The process and steps were clearly defined in a YouTube video I found.  The difficult part was making sure I did not break the keyboard when trying to remove it.  The plastic feels very brittle.  It took some time before I felt comfortable applying enough pressure for it to come off.

As far as general use, the keyboard feels rather flimsy and cheap.  When you type you can feel the keyboard "dip down".  With the added SSD the computer boots in a few seconds and feels very snappy with general use.  We will see how the speed holds up over time.  This laptop is very good for general users who do not have process intensive tasks.  I would recommend this product.

**UPDATE 2**
I am bumping this up another star but will not give it 5 due to Asus Support.  I cloned and swapped the HDD out of the new laptop with an SSHD.  It will take a few uses for the new drive to determine what programs my wife uses the most but I already see an increase in speed.  I slapped in a 8gb of ram to increase memory to 12gb.

Bottom line, this computer is a decent buy IF you or someone you know can work on laptops.  Look at it as if you don't really have a warranty aside for DOA devices.  My only concern, when the original laptop's HDD died, was how windows was set up.  What version of 7/8 was originally on it and what were the steps I would need to do in order to get the operating system on a new HDD (since I don't have a windows key and it looks like it was a win10 upgrade)?  Those are questions that Asus must be able to answer.  And telling me that I should have bought the computer from best buy is not an acceptable answer.  This laptop is a best seller on Amazon - you guys need to be prepared to offer support for online purchases that is on par with the support for purchases made at a brick and mortar store.

**UPDATE**
Amazon to the rescue.  Amazon agreed to send me a new laptop.  The replacement laptop is configured differently.  The original HDD had several partitions on on it while the new one is just a single partition - i found that strange.  The original laptop prompted me to register the unit when I did the initial set up but this new one didn't.  Also, the replacement touchpad is sitting above the casing opposed to slighly indented below the casing.  Amazon said it was supposed to a brand new one but I have my doubts.

Bottom line, if this laptop was for me, I would have taken the refund instead.  But this is for my wife and her school and art work.  She likes it so I am fine with the replacement.

Just don't expect Asus Support to be any help.  I am sure Amazon would interested to know that the Asus support agent repeatedly said I should have purchased this from Best Buy because it is easier for them to "repair."

** INITIAL REVIEW**
Listen to the other reviews and replace that HDD ASAP.  I thought we would try out the laptop with the original HDD for a few months then upgrade to an SSD or SSHD...my mistake.  Was great for the first 3 months.  Then the HDD completely failed and the nightmare began.  I tried to clone - no deal, too many bad sectors.  I have contacted ASUS multiple times too and their only response is for me to send them back the entire laptop for repair but they were also unable to supply me with a time frame.  One agent said maybe 8 weeks: absolutely unacceptable, my wife needs this for her business and school.  I then just asked how could i get a windows disc so i could just replace the HDD myself and was told that i needed to buy the retail version of windows 10 because ASUS only supplies windows xp, vista and 7 discs per their customer service.

ASUS must stand for A Sucker (gets) Used Sometimes. What a piece of junk, this laptop took a powder within 24 hours. It doesn't hold an internet connection, the pre-installed programs don't work well and the DVD/CD port is flimsy. I will turn this is ASAP! and won't buy another.

This is an excellent buy. After reading so many negative reviews, I just had to let you know my experience, one from a highly technical person who has not only used and repaired, but prepped hundreds and hundreds of new laptops.
I ordered it Tuesday night, it arrived Wednesday afternoon. Yes, it would have been free two-day shipping with Prime, but I couldn't wait, so I paid the extra pittance of $11 for one day shipping.
I was surprised by the large box that I was able to shake and feel contents easily move around. When opened, it was just the laptop box with a strip of paper keeping it from sliding to the edges of the larger box. The laptop box itself packed the laptop well enough I don't think this made much difference. However (are you listening Amazon?), I would have been MUCH happier if the smaller box was completely held in place more securely.

As to the laptop...
I gave it 5 stars, yet it's really, for me, about 4 and 1/2, maybe 4 and 3/4 stars. An outstanding value for the price, with just a couple of things I wished they had made easier from a (techie) consumer point of view. Namely, the inability to remove the battery and, the difficulty in changing out the included hard drive for an SSD and, being able to only add one (1) memory module (as opposed to being able to take out the included RAM and add TWO much larger modules).
Battery: I like to take out the battery when I have this plugged in at home and only put it back in when I take it out on the road. Most laptop batteries last about 300 charges - or for most people - about 1 year, before they begin to lose their charge very quickly. This is normal. I have laptops that still hold a charge for 2-5 hours that are over 5 years old because I plug them in, without the battery installed, every chance I get.

Hard Drive: The included 5400 rpm Hard Drive is fine. Large enough for most people and was zippy enough, taking only 41 seconds to boot to the desktop when I was finished installing my Anti-virus, games and office programs. BUT, an SSD is much, much faster. (may  take under 10 seconds to boot?) In fact, I bought a 256GB Samsung 850 EVO SSD (solid state drive) to replace the original "spinning platter" (like a phonograph record) drive. However, the laborious task of completely taking apart the shell, just to get to the hard drive AND the fact that the included drive is actually working fine (for now?) is putting me off on making the swap, even though I've already prepped the SSD.
 I've done this with many, many laptops. It's not actually all that difficult. BUT you absolutely must take great care when pulling things apart. It is EXTREMELY easy to tear out hidden ribbons and cables. Making that task, particularly on a laptop I've never done it on before, take an especially long, slow, and careful experience. I'm just not sure I want to take the time since it already works fine. Maybe this weekend, if I have the time. I'll edit if I do. First I want to test it out with the basic defaults.

RAM: The included 4GB memory is fine for most purposes. Adding another 8GB stick just allows me to do more things at once. However, I would have liked the opportunity to add TWO 8 GB sticks and have 16GBs instead of only 12GB.
It did take me less than 3 minutes to add a new stick. Less than a minute to open the packaging, about a minute to unscrew and pop the RAM cover on the bottom of the computer, and about a minute to insert it, and put the cover back in place.
*Note: if you do this, be sure to handle ONLY THE EDGES of the stick and insert it at a 45 degree angle, ALL the way in, before pushing it down in place. Also, obviously, be sure the laptop is unplugged and turned off.
**Note 2: The makers covered up the screw with a tiny piece of stick paper. If you take a small sharp knife, you should be able to gently lift if up from the corner, leave it on the knife and replace it after screwing everything back down.

Here are the reasons I believe this is an outstanding value:
- Large screen. Full HD (High Definition). 1920x1080. Many laptops this size use much larger pixels so things appear larger, but you actually see less on the screen.
  *Note: This was also one of the detractors. The 15" screen is nearly as large as my 17" laptop's screen. It has very wide bezels
- 500 GB hard drive. I would expect to pay another $100-$200 for a 1TB drive to be included. So this was fair.

- 2 USB 3.0 slots. USB 1.0 con transfer only 1.5MB per second (MBps), 2.0 is forty times that at 60MBps, and USB 3.0 is 10x faster than that! At 640MBps. AMAZINGLY fast if backing up to an external drive. And you get TWO of them, woot!
- Wi-Fi of 802.11ac. Most laptops are still touting 802.11n. Which is much better and faster than 802.11g. But "ac" is 3x faster than that!
PLUS.. you get the advantage of being able to handle connections to both 2.4GHz AND 5GHz at the same time.
Let me explain.. Think of yourself having a conversation with someone in normal tones, and having a mosquito buzzing. Two different tones, or frequencies, but both clearly able to be heard, at the same time. Then imagine having a conversation with TWO people, both speaking in normal tones, at the same time. Difficult to really catch what one is saying over the other. Well, that's what the two frequencies help with. While most others around you are using 802.11n/b/g (all running at 2.4GHz), kind of like having a small room full of people speaking at the same time with their voices echoing back and becoming jumbled and hard to hear, you can be using the 5GHz frequency which isn't interfered with by all the other voices. You could also be using your Bluetooth devices at the same time, and having little to no interference. Nowadays, Bluetooth headsets, microphones, mice, keyboards, 802.11b/g/n devices and even microwave ovens, all interfere with each other at the 2.4GHz level.

- A DVD read/writer that both reads AND writes to normal DVDs AND DUAL Layer DVD's. *instead of only 4.7GBs you get 8.4GBs per side!

- CPU: A Dual-Core i3 that includes "Hyper-threading" and runs at 2.1GHz. Yes, you're paying for that. Many laptops for $100 less are running "atom" processors at only 1.6 or 1.8 GHZ. Much, much slower, and less able to run multiple things at the same time.
*Note: "Hyper-Threading" helps the CPU process things about 37% faster. For example, lets say there are two ticket takers in the movie theater, taking tickets from 2 lines of people. Obviously this is much faster than only 1 ticket taker, but not really *twice* as fast, since hey still have to wait for each person to shuffle forward with their ticket, which they may or may not have immediately ready to hand to the ticket-taker.
Now think of a third line, a "standby" line. Where, while a ticket-taker is waiting for someone in the main line to shuffle forward or get their ticket ready, they can take a ticket from the next person in the "stand-by" line.
(**BTW: This is also why a Core-i5 CPU is faster than a Core-i3. It doesn't have 'Hyper-threading", but instead has 4 cores instead of two. So it can have 4 dedicated lines - without any standby line. And a Core-i7 has 4 cores AND 'hyperthreading').

- Keyboard: Large, with soft/quiet feel on the keys, yet with decent tactile touches. It also includes a 10-key. (keys 0-9) on the side.
*Note: This was also a point of contention for me, both the overall size of the screen and keyboard. More on those at the bottom of this review.
- External Video Outputs: Both an HDMI AND a VGA connector. So I can hook-up to TVs in hotel rooms to watch Netflix or my own movies off the laptop, And/or will easily connect to any projectors out there. You have to supply your own cable(s) of course.
*This will also connect to a 2nd or larger monitor. Most will accept one or the other of the connections.

- Gigabit Ethernet (the *wired* connection using a cable/cord): Again, not just the normal, and completely acceptable 100mbps (Megabits per second) of most laptops, but a Gigabit or 1,000mbps connection that is 10 times faster. Now.. this will obviously make NO difference in a hotel room, business meeting etc, where the standard actually is only "Fast Ethernet" or 100mbps. However, if you're at home, or your office where you have a full gigabit connectivity (That is your laptop, the ethernet cable or cord, the connector in the wall, the lines through the building, the switch(es), drop points and router, etc. If ALL are gigabit capable) you will be able to connect to your internal servers, printers or other computers/servers on your network 10x faster. Copy, upload, download, stream, all much, much faster!

* A note on additional items and value:
Adding to the laptop the extra RAM (I got from Amazon also, as recommended by another reviewer, and it works great)
Kingston HyperX Impact Black 8GB 1600MHz DDR3L CL9 SODIMM 1.35V Laptop Memory (HX316LS9IB/8) @ $36
I know have a Fast, capable laptop right at $400.
Even adding the SSD (Samsung 850 EVO 250GB 2.5-Inch SATA III Internal SSD (MZ-75E250B/AM) ,@ $86
and a wireless mouse (TeckNet Pro 2.4G Wireless Mouse,Nano Receiver,6 Buttons,24 Month Battery Life,2400 DPI 3 Adjustment Levels ) @ $9 still puts me under $500 for an outstanding laptop that blows anything else at that price point out of the water.
I would expect to pay at least another $100 if I wanted a Core-i5 CPU. But really, I'm not using it for gaming. But am using it for more than just email and surfing the web. I expect to have multiple web browser windows open running google docs, google map searches, LogMeIn. At the same time running Word, Excel, Outlook, streaming music, and some kind of camera like the built in webcam or an external for surveillance or Skype, while either burning or copying DVD's... all at the same time.
I expect this Core-i3 will handle all of that easily, and then some.
** I will update my experiences on that after usage.

Currently I highly recommend this product if, that is, you don't mind the large keyboard and overall size almost at par with a 17" model.

My first Impressions:
Opening the laptop box was a fun experience. Not difficult at all, just nice. I won't add any spoiler in case you order one.
As another reviewer mentioned, I was surprised that it turned on immediately as I plugged it in. But, no worries, I was going to turn it on in the next second or two anyway.
I did NOT find it to be "plasticky" or "cheap" feeling. Instead the outside and keyboard are firm enough and.. made of a material that won't show fingerprints.
I was also very surprised and quite happily excited to find the almost complete lack of "Bloatware" or "Adware" that other reviewers said they had. That is, programs and applications with icons scattered across the screen for things that most people don't want, or need, but still click on and install because they either don't know what the programs are for, or that they think they need to install them, etc.
Most people who complain about Bloatware probably don't realize that is how many companies are able to offer their products at a low price point. The Adware/Bloatware manufacturers pay the laptop company for space on the screen/hard drive, and in return, the laptop company passes savings onto us.
However.. this laptop (the ASUS F555LA-AB31 15.6-inch Full-HD Laptop (Core i3, 4GB RAM, 500GB HDD) with Windows 10) didn't have ANY extra or included "bloatware" that I could see. Only extra stuff from Microsoft like Xbox connection, 3D power, MS Money, OneNote, etc. and a couple of ASUS items. All of which were/are perfectly acceptable items that you actually might like to use. Not really considered bloatware at all.

Also.. if it HAD included anything I didn't want, I would simply have gone into the Add/Remove programs setting and just deleted them. Done.

A note on setup:
- A couple of reviewers mentioned they had viruses/malware either right out of the box or shortly thereafter.
Now.. it *could* be that was a computer that was returned after having been infected by it's previous owner and somehow slipped through cracks of the process designed to receive used laptops, refurbish/wipe out/reinstall the drives.
But honestly, I feel confident that most people with those experiences simply infected themselves through lack of knowledge.
The moment you plug your computer, any computer with (especially) Windows into a working network, either wired or wireless, you are opening yourself to becoming attacked and possibly infected. If you put a computer onto the internet without any kind of protection it is quite possible for it to become infected within JUST A FEW MINUTES!
Possibly from other computers on your home network!!!

So... BEFORE connecting to ANY network, you want to make sure your PC is ready, and as protected as possible.
There are plenty of places telling you what to do to set up Windows 10 and such, so I'll just include the basics of what to do/have ready, before you connect to the network.
- Ensure Windows Defender is Turned ON (yes I know, it's not that powerful, but you'll be installing a GOOD Anti-virus/Firewall in a couple of minutes
- Create a "Repair Disk" (just in case anything goes wonky in the next few minutes, or year)
- Make a backup to either an external hard drive or DVDs (this will take only 2 dual layer DVDs or 4 regular recordable ones)
 *If you backup to an external drive (USB), be sure to include a "system image" with it.
- Turn on System Restore, give yourself about 10% of your drive for this.
- Install a good 3rd party Anti-virus/Firewall program such as Norton, Kapersky, McAfee, Webroot, Bitdefender, Avast, AVG, ESET, etc.
- Go online and FIRST update your anti-malware program (the one above you just installed).
- Update Windows.
Finally, don't click on any link in ANY email, unless you are absolutely sure you know where it's coming from and taking you. There are websites being created every single day to thwart/bypass all your current security procedures. You aren't protected from the new threats until your antivirus company finds them, creates a protection from them, and you download that protection.
Just because the email is from your mom, and the link says, "I love you" doesn't mean it's actually from your mom (although she still probably loves you). If you're not sure.. (I have several non-techie family members that forward stuff to me all the time without any explanation), but you believe the email is from someone you trust, email them back (DON'T hit [Reply], the return address might just be the spammer/infector) and ask if they sent it, and why.

Things I didn't like:
- Windows 10, Home edition: Getting the home edition may be fine for most people who just do stuff at home or school. But if the laptop includes Intel VT (Virtual Technology) which this one does, you can't use it with the "Home" edition.
Okay, okay. I realize most people don't use VT.. yet. But I do, and so do many other techies like me. If I have an extra CPU (I do) and some extra RAM (I do), then I could create what's known as a "virtual machine". Sort of like another computer within the computer, and install a completely different OS (operating system) on it like Windows XP, Vista, Windows 7 or Linux, and use it - completely separate from the "host" OS - as either a test bed (we call it a "sandbox" cause you can just go in and play around in it, then either save or undo the changes you made) for checking out new programs and such. OR.. run an OS like Linux on it, and use it as a server or as a completely different tool for a ton of different purposes.

It would have been MUCH better to have included Windows 7 pro (or even the horrid Windows8), both of which include a free upgrade to Windows 10 (as long as you do it before July 29, 2016). Personally, I'm quite happy with Windows 7. Especially if I'm not gaming.
So.. now, in order to use the VT, I have to either pay for an upgrade to Windows 10 Pro/Ultimate or Wipe everything out, Install a pro/ultimate version of windows 7 and use the free upgrade to Windows 10.

The Size - it's HUGE:(see my picture)
Ok.. this is a minor pet peeve. I actually expected this laptop to be quite a bit smaller than my 17" model. It's not.
It's only about an inch less wide, and 1/2 an inch less deep. The actual LCD screen size is
13 1/2 x 7 3/4 (15.5 in diagonal) this laptop vs
15" x 8 1/2 (17.25 in diagonal) on the 17" laptop.
But the bezel outside the screen is nearly 1/2" wider on each side than the 17".
Even the keyboard is larger. This laptop 13.5 x 4 1/8" vs. the 17" laptop at 13.25 x 3 7/8!
I mean, I enjoy having the 10 key (even without the "Number lock" indicator light) but to have the keys that spread apart is just ridiculous to me. Personally I don't mind having the keys crammed together as in the picture of the 14" laptop on the left, as long as they are full-sized keys AND laid out in a proper QWERTY style. But to have them spread out as wide (or wider) as a stand alone keyboard... ugh. Moreover, there's the whole "palm rest" portion. I don't know about you, but I'm a big guy, over 6 feet tall, with proportionately large hands, and even I don't need all that extra real-estate to rest my arms on. Easily could have taken an entire inch off the depth, as well as nearly an entire inch off the width.

So.. in conclusion, with all the above being said, if you don't mind a 'Home' version of Windows, a spread out keyboard and larger than needed overall size, the inability to remove the battery, the ability to only add one additional RAM stick, difficulty swapping out the hard drive to an SSD, and the lack of any indicator lights (Caps Lock, Num Lock, etc.) but want a computer for a great price, that's fast, will multi-task well, comes with pretty much all the bells and whistles you could ask for (802.11ac, Gigabit Ethernet, Full HD screen, HDMI as well as VGA and VT if you want to upgrade to a Windows Pro version, etc.; then this is for you.
An outstanding buy for most people. An excellent purchase for me.
I highly recommend it.

My mother visited me recently and I got a first-hand look at her personal laptop. In short, it was a mess - buggy, full of viruses and prone to spontaneous crashes. I knew that she depended on her laptop to keep in touch with family and friends so something had to be done.

A binge of researching led me to the ASUS F55LA. I ordered it with and additional 8 gigs of RAM as well as a  Samsung 850 EVO 250GB solid state drive. Don't be deterred from upgrading the hard drive - the 850 EVO comes with the necessary software to clone the hard drive and it is pretty much idiot proof. The hardest part is opening up the machine to swap the drives and there are several videos online that walk you through the process.

Seriously folks, enhancing this laptop with these upgrades makes it into a very capable machine. My 'daily driver' is a 15" MacBook Pro and I felt very comfortable working with this laptop. It is fast, light and runs cool. The battery life is about 4 hours which is sufficient for a non-business user.

The biggest drawback is the screen - it has very limited viewing angles. But once you find the 'sweet spot' and crank the brightness to max it's not a bad viewing experience. Windows 10 is also not all that bad, and this is coming from an OSX fan. It will be perfect for Mom as it is very close to the Windows 7 she's used to. It even comes with Windows Defender, Microsoft's take on their own virus protection software.

Bottom line, for $500 you can get a decent laptop.  Highly recommended and I'm sure it will be a hit with Mom. :)

Initial review as of March 29th, 2016.
After a lot of time spent researching computers I ended up getting this laptop. I wanted an affordable, reliable, powerful machine that can handle some bigger applications. So far, I really like it. I took the advice of some other folks and did some upgrading. This laptop now boots in 8 seconds and loads applications in eye blinks. Only gripe so far is battery life, which seems like it should be higher for a brand new laptop. But I can't complain, I just switched from a 6 year-old laptop that had zero battery life. I also read that some folks thought this device generally has a cheap feeling. I disagree - it feels fine to me and Asus computers are known for being reliable.

I got a 250 GB Solid State Drive for it, which is basically an advanced type of hard drive.
http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00OAJ412U/ref=twister_B00PRDMHLU?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1

When the new SSD goes in, the old hard drive comes out, and you can turn that old hard drive into a 500 GB mass storage device for backing up computers and storing a ton of files.
http://www.amazon.com/Upgraded-Sabrent-2-5-Inch-Enclosure-EC-UM30/dp/B00MQ97QGE/ref=sr_1_3?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1459290627&sr=1-3&keywords=sabrent+2.5+ssd+sata+hard+drive+usb+3.0+enclosure

Finally I got 8 GB of RAM to upgrade this laptop. This lets the computer operate with reduced strain. Don't criticize my technological explanations here, I'm just a common folk with minimal knowledge regarding computer specs.
http://www.amazon.com/Crucial-PC3-12800-204-Pin-Notebook-CT102464BF160B/dp/B006YG8X9Y?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00

The total investment was $370 for the laptop, $87 for the SSD, $45 to pay someone to install the SSD, $33 for the 8 GB of RAM, and $10 for the external hard drive case. So for about $550 I ended up with a 250 GB SSD, 12 GB RAM, blazing fast computer, plus a mass storage device.

Regarding the hardware installation: the RAM is very easy to do, you just open up a little slot at the bottom of the computer and stick it in like a battery. Putting in the Solid State Drive is a lot more involved for this computer though (as in taking the whole thing apart). I called Asus and asked if it would be okay to perform hardware installation and they said yes, but if anything breaks, you lose your 1 year warranty. This is why I had the Solid State Drive professionally installed. I worry about this kind of stuff, but I'm sure it wouldn't be too complicated to do on your own. Had I waited a year for the warranty to expire and get the SSD, I probably would've tried myself.

I'll be updating my review in a few months.

I caution others to stay away from this model. It's only been a month and this computer's hard drive is getting more troublesome everyday as I am continually getting BSoD and BIOs reboot looping stemming from a multitude of memory failures. Very disappointed!!!!

Love it!  Great product so far.  Arrived on time and was packaged safely.  Pleased so far with product.

Pro:
Great battery life - ~6 hours.

Con:
Wireless card didn't play nice with Linux Mint.
Chassis and internal screws strip EXTREMELY easily.

I bought this because my prior laptop bit the dust.

When I bought this I immediately removed the hard disk and replaced it with an 850 EVO SSD, removed the optical drive, and placed the mechanical drive in a caddy where the optical drive was. I then performed a fresh install of Linux Mint Cinnamon. Everything worked out of the box, with no configuration necessary.

I noticed that when I was on campus my machine had trouble connecting to the WiFi, and if I turned off the wireless adapter and restarted it, the machine would freeze and require a hard reset. I replaced the wireless card with an Intel 7260. HMWG.R and the problems went away completely.

This machine definitely has enough oomph for just about any task you throw at it. The only time I notice any sort of lag or stuttering is when doing extremely resource-intensive tasks, as is to be expected with nearly every machine. Unless you're actively attempting to make the machine run slow, you'll definitely have plenty of processing power.

I was disappointed when opening the machine [ to add an SSD, remove the optical drive, and swap the wireless card ] to find that all the screws are made of softer metal and strip easily. I almost completely stripped one internal screw holding the hdd caddy in place.

I cannot comment on how the machine runs stock - I've never run any sort of Windows on it, nor have I ever booted it from a mechanical drive.

Using the machine is nice. The touchpad works well, it boots in ~10 seconds, battery lasts ~6 hours. The keyboard has a touch of flex in it, but the overall build quality is very good. I may put another 8GB of RAM in the machine at a later date, but I haven't needed even the full 4GB so far. As an aside, the 4GB that comes with the machine  is soldered onto the board - there is one free slot which can accommodate up to 8GB for a total of 12GB max in the machine.

Plenty of reviews here pointing out the pros and cons of this laptop so I will keep it simple and to the point.

What I like:
-  The 1080P screen is very vice and well worth the price paid whether with this laptop or any other.
-  Overall quality for the price is very good.
-  Processor is quite snappy
-  Keyboard isn't nearly as bad as I have read in other reviews
-  Laptop is very quiet.  No hard drive noise and very little fan noise due to a cool running CPU
-  Only used one memory slot so upgrading to 8 or 12 gb of RAM is less expensive
-  Access to memory slots is easy

What I don't like:
-  The touchpad is has the button click feature over the entire pad area which makes tapping the surface feel less solid
-  It is hard to tell when your finger is over the right or left mouse button as the entire touchpad surface is sooth
-  I am not a fan of the charger.  It is too short since the brick part plugs directly into the wall socket
-  The battery is internal but this is the case with most newer laptops
-  The laptop has to have the bottom cover removed to access/replace the hard drive.  Again, most newer laptops are the same
-  Would rather have the speaker ports on top and under the screen.  They are placed under the leading lower edge.  So far not a
  big issue though regarding sound playback

So overall, I am satisfied with this laptop.  Especially considering the price.  There is nothing out there that I could find that offered an i3 CPU and a 1080p screen for anywhere near the price.  I can't say enough how nice it is to have a 1080p screen on a 15"+ laptop.  I will never buy a laptop with a resolution less than 1080p again.

I added 8gb additional ram for a total of 12gb. I also changed out the HD with a Samsung 850 EVO 250gb SSD. Battery life is decent, lasts for several hours. Laptop runs _cool_. I run a couple virtual machines using virtualbox, surf the web, chat / email programs and everything operates smoothly. I'm not actively trying to max out the CPU but it seems to multitask fairly well. Touchpad is nice, but I still prefer a mouse so I bought a Logitech trackball m570. I read some reviews on here prior to buying this that complained about the keyboard. I'm able to type without issue. My only complaint about the keyboard is there are no LED indicator lights for the LOCK buttons. The RAM compartment has a BLACK sticker on it which looks like the rest of the case(sabotage). Just scratch it off and then you'll see the head of a screw. This is a great buy. I'm happy with it. Love the 1920x1080 full HD resolution. Installed openSUSE LEAP 42.1(Linux) and everything works 100% out of the box. CON: May not be able to swap out battery easily if at all.(The battery doesn't plug in like traditional laptops).ASUS F555LA-AB31 15.6-inch Full-HD Laptop (Core i3, 4GB RAM, 500GB HDD) with Windows 10

This laptop is a great for the price. I have used other laptops with the older Core i3 cpus and they were not very tolerable. Especially the lenovo I use at work. I hate that thing. It boots up lightning quick now that I have a solid state drive and low intensity applications run as fast as my custom built desktop. The feel is definitely not bad for the price. It does have a cheaper plastic feel to it, but what would you expect for the price?  I find the silver color of the body and track pad to be a little annoying from the glare from the screen so I ordered a brushed black aluminum vinyl wrap for the lid and keyboard tray. Aesthetically it will make it much more pleasing as well.

I wouldn't expect to run modern games on this laptop but that is honestly not what I bought it for. By far it is the best laptop for under 500. There isn't even another option I would consider unless it had a 1080p screen. The viewing angle of the screen is  a little poor but I find it is not much of a concern as I am sitting directly in front of it when I use it anyways. All in all I would totally recommend this laptop to anyone who wants a cheap laptop to do basic work on. Just don't expect miracles out of a 350 dollar laptop and you will be happy with it.

I purchased this computer from Amazon exactly one month ago.  While I seldom write reviews, I was so satisfied with this product and with the job that Asus has done for us here that I felt it was necessary for me to at least give my impression briefly.  I was working on an aging HP laptop, about 4 years old, which gave me excellent service over the time I had it.  Having gone through many computers, I can honestly say that  that the most satisfaction of "having made a deal" has come from this one.  For the price, the screen quality is outstanding, the machine boots in 6 to 10 seconds and shuts down completely in about the same amount of time. I only have 7 of my own programs installed because that's really all I need and I keep the programs out of Startup.  The original HDD is in place, as I see no reason for installing an SSD at this time.  I have deleted none of the programs that were bundled by Asus because I didn't find them to be obtrusive or excessive.  I was able to install the Kingston 8GB memory module that someone else recommended here in less that 5 minutes and now have 12Gigs of memory (I'm not sure about the pairing of the memory to 4GB on-board and 4GB expanded but 12 sounded better than eight to me, for those interested in expanding the on-board memory this should probably be reasearched).  One important point here that you will all see causing problems if you go through the reviews is that, for some reason, Asus has covered the Phillips screw to the cover of the casing of the memory module with a rubber circle exactly matching the head of the screw.  This is confusing because it is not obvious that there is a screw there at all. This lead one of the reviewers here to think that the cover was of the snap off variety.  Unfortunately, in trying to pry it out, he ended up breaking it.

Other than that small point, this is a quite solid machine, beautifully engineered IMHO, and with several features just not found in a sub-$500 laptop, such as:  the bright and quite beautiful 1920x1080p resolution screen,  the "adequate" 5th generation Broadwell processor, the 80211 A/C WiFi, Bluetooth 4 (don't take it for granted), and an unbelievable one year warranty that *includes drops and spills.*  In essence, this could be a machine for some who doesn't need the bleeding edge of technology, but who wants to keep themselves up date with a machine that looks good, performs well, and will fend for itself until the next one comes along.

Out of the box, It has " Good Looks.", bare bones,  just what I have dreamed about for some time. Works pretty good stock, can't quite imagine how it will run after I start getting the right stuff to complete upgrades to Samsung 850 ssd, extra stick of ram memory,

I want to use the hhd as an external b/u but I don't have an enclosure because not sure what to buy yet. Also have to see if I need any cables , screws, install brackets??I will find out when I get a look inside the box.  Have reviewed the videos and feel confident on the task at hand.  I have also decided to use a fresh  windows 10 stick to do a clean install of 10,  I  will need it for another 5 year old HP laptop I have which needs some new hardware and OS 10 from Vista. Not sure yet if its going to be doable.

UPDATE:
Okay got the remaining upgrade components today. Installed the ram memory stick  (8g additional),that was easy.
Amazon delivery by post office was split into two delivery days then still missing a couple of things,  rest showed two hours later by UPS guy. SO,finally decided to change the hard drive but I was wondering if I needed special cables going HHD to SSD drive?  Decided to take another look at u-tube and found a short video on drive installation. He was doing a F555LA ASUS.  Great! Just what I needed at the moment. This guy works fast,he changed the drive in 6 MINUTES.  From the time he removed the screws, popped the cover, swapped drives,re-installed, replaced cover,  flipped it over, pushed the WIN 10 on a Zip drive into the usb socket,  power on, started loading the OS. WOW! That was s fast. Now I said I can do that, maybe  15 minutes. Turns out he didn't need any additional hardware for mounting the drive or different cables. He re-used the old ribbon cables. 4 connections,  that's it. I was completely off base thinking I needed something different,  I was confusing the drive cloning procedure where you would have the old drive patched in (during the copy) to the new Samsung 850 sata ssd. I wasn't putting any data from my old HP laptop into the new F555LA ASUS  laptop.
To me the zip drive Win 10 was the way to go.  The young man did it in 6 minutes, it took me about 35 minutes from start of drive install to finish loading the Windows 10. I never said I knew anything about computers. Lol. This thing boots in15 seconds. Darn, I am a happy man, getting a little geeky. Ha!
Now I need to run the  read/write tests to see how fast the new drive is running. Any program suggestions for the testing? Free. Thanks folks.  Love this Asus F555LA. Now need my girlfriend to get a few software packages at the University, which are very reasonably priced.  I want to keep this box clean, no . garbage programs.  I should run from a virtual drive. Happy trails.

Had the laptop 3 months now, and it works very well. It's quiet, has a nice sized screen, good resolution, decent graphics card, power cord is long, boot up is very quick, and win10 is a fine OS. To all the people leaving negative reviews for mostly innocuous issues, let me remind you that you're paying $375 for a Windows 10 laptop with a Full HD screen and an i3 processor.  That alone should make you question whether or not to leave a bad review, but if it doesn't, then filter your search for i3 processors and see what average price for other laptops are.  This laptop, for the price, is the best deal you'll find on the internet.

I received this laptop about two weeks ago and took the advice from other reviewers by upgrading the RAM and changing the HDD to a SSD, and honestly, I'm not sure I could ask for a better machine for a total cost of about $500.  Yes, the keyboard is a bit flimsy and certainly not as nice as the keyboard on my girlfriend's MacBook Air, and yes, the track pad is slightly eratic.  But you just paid $375 for it!  If you expect the quality of a $1,100 computer, then you're going to have to suck it up and pay $1,100 for a computer.

The computer came out of the box operating pretty quickly with the 4 GB of RAM and the regular HDD, so if you're not comfortable opening the machine up and making the upgrades, this computer will still be perfectly sufficient.  But, those of you willing to make the upgrades, holy crap.  This machine, with the extra 8 GB of RAM and the SSD, is an absolute powerhouse.  Just yesterday, I had about 10 Chrome tabs open, composing a message in Outlook while casting (in the background) some media to my ROKU, and this computer didn't so much as hiccup.

I'm glad to answer any questions anyone might have.
