For the price of $375.00, this laptop actually runs extremely well.  After using it for about a week, I'm already happy that I had purchased this laptop.
First off, I'd like to mention that I've installed a Samsung Evo 500GB SSD as well as another stick of 8GB RAM into the laptop and this runs a lot faster than my old laptop I had been using for four years up until now.  Boot up time went from 1 min to about 10-15 secs with no problems.  I'm currently in college, so this laptop is definitely beneficial as I've been using it constantly for coding as well as typing documents.  It's good for everyday use and I've found that it can handle continuous use on a battery charge for quite a while.  The longest it's handled without being charged was about 4 hours, which in my opinion, handles pretty well.  The computer itself runs well, I've had no problems with it slowing down on me, and it is extremely light.

So for this price:
375 for the laptop,
150 for the SSD
35 for the 8GB RAM

This $560 laptop runs just as well as my old laptop, while definitely beating it in terms of speed.  If you're looking for something to game with however, this can only handle certain games at medium to medium high graphic settings. It will definitely not be sufficient enough for graphic intensive games like GTA V or Fallout 4 if you're aiming for 'ultra' settings in these games.  It can handle games like League of Legends however with around 40-50 fps.  The onboard graphics is more than enough to handle basic gaming so keep that in mind before purchasing this laptop.

Pros:
2 USB 3.0 slots allows for faster transfer speeds
Extremely light
HD Screen (1920 * 1080 resolution)
Full Sized Keyboard
Nice specs for a cheap price.

Cons:
I'd like to point out that it only has one output for audio, and this is for your headphones.  If you're looking for another port for the microphones, you'll need to find an adapter to connect both inputs into as this does not have a microphone jack.
The keyboard is not backlit, and don't expect to be able to replace it for a backlit one.  It's not removable unless you take off the entire panel to change it out.
Hard to access the drive within. Screws are extremely easy to strip so be careful when taking out screws.
Great Laptop!

I'm giving this 4 stars. However, if you add more RAM and a SSD as some reviewers have suggested, this is definitely a 5-star option. So, you need to decide whether it's worth the hassle of opening the computer and replacing RAM/HD for about additional $150 or so. This is a cool little project if you like to mess with gadgets (the reason I bought this). The upgrade items/procedure listed by one of the reviewers here seems to be accurate (thanks for sharing). I added 8 GB of RAM and a 250 GB Samsung SSD. This change does elevate this computer to $600-800 range in terms of performance. Given it comes with a good 1080p display, the upgrade is well worth, if you can DIY. Probably not worth if you plan to pay someone for this. If you plan to use the default configuration (i.e. 4GB RAM and a regular 5400 RPM HD) then you need to understand that the performance is somewhat sluggish, although useable in most day to day applications such as web browsing, e-mail, and word-processing applications.

this is a good computer for the price. fast and functional, but requires a little dialing in to get to work properly. windows 10 was a little buggy at first and was highly susceptible to viruses before i was able to get kaspersky downloaded and installed. after i installed another 8 GB of ram (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006YG8X9Y?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01) which was easy to install and worked great right out of the box (install instructions: [...] /watch?v=yecuhZDw0hs) and installed all windows 10 updates (settings = windows update, note: may have to restart and download updates multiple times before everything is fully updated), and got my anti virus up and running, i was good to go. highly impressed with the speed and sound of this budget laptop. i actually like windows 10 once fully updated because it's easy to update settings, download drivers for printers and other devices, and works well with 3rd party apps, like kaspersky antivirus which manages windows firewall, etc. if you don't mind tweaking this system a little, you will be happy with the purchase.

My disappointment is twofold first the info on the keyboard I can't read without a magnifying glass that includes the secondary use on the full sized keys like the ? Symbol.

I have arthritis and find that the keys require more force than I have had to exert on my previous machine.

We're it not for illegibility of keys I would have awarded another star but that fault coupled with the strange numbering of the "f" keys find me constantly reaching for reading assistance.  The keys read from the left 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 10, 11, 12.  I'm sure that in time I shall have them all memorized but it seem such a minor thing to have fixed during design phase.  I should note that reading scores for both eyes 20/ so that while I've been around for a while and don't see the far mountains as clearly as in the past I read with out glasses.

All the above do not make it a bad choice but if  you have the afflictions of age as I do you may wish to search on.

I was able to download Chrome and Firefox by disabling Windows Defender temporarily, so that is one fix for those having trouble doing the downloads.
 Since it doesn't have a media player driver without paying Microsoft for it, I downloaded the VLC media player for free which works quite well, in my opinion. The clarity of the screen is awesome. You can change the brightness by tapping notifications, selecting how bright you want it to be. Be warned the brighter you make it the more of the battery charge is used. I have found 50% is best for my needs.
 The system is a bit slow out of the box but I haven't done any upgrades yet, and for the price of the unit it is well worth the extra investment. Even better for me I happened to buy it a week before the price went up another $25.00.
 I have had no issues with the touch pad although it is quite sensitive, but I think practice will make make it easier. To me the keyboard seems very stable. Of course this is my first laptop so I have no other standard by which to compare it.
 I will be updating my review after I upgrade the hardware or if any issues arise. i would not hesitate to recommend this to potential buyers as of this date.

Edit your review: Update: 04/03/2016 I have now had My  ASUS F555LA-AB31 15.6-inch Full-HD Laptop (Core i3, 4GB RAM, 500GB HDD) with Windows 10.for two months now and I am still thoroughly pleased with it. I have had no problems with it to date. I  upgraded the memory to have a total of 12 GB. I also upgrade to the newest Windows 10 version with ease. But be warned this version does not support Bluetooth. I don't know if there is a way around that yet but I'm not too concerned right now. I found it easy to learn the new OS after coming from years of windows 7. To me the clarity of the screen is good, even at 50% brightness. It is true that the viewing angle is not good, but it is only a minor inconvenience. I use a remote keyboard and mouse to save  wear and tear to the onboard touchpad and keyboard. If you're like me (and not extremely familiar with the i series of Intel processors), you might snub your nose at the i3. That's probably a mistake, especially at this point. These i3s(and the entire family) have come a long way since they were introduced to market. When they first came out an i3 was somewhere along the lines of an atom processor and only suitable for the bare minimum. Now, these are pretty great. This 5010u model is ranked at 226 on this notebookcheck.net. 226 might not sound great in your mind (but most processors above it are i7 or i5 and will probably cost you close to or more than 1k). 226 is more than enough for anyone but graphics editors or someone who expects to play fallout4 at 1920x1080p with AA at 4x on a laptop (even then the i3 wouldn't be your biggest bottleneck). My 2012 Acer with A8-4500m is ranked 397, and while there isn't a huge real world difference, there is definitely some extra "pop" with the i3. I'm not sure that it will perform as well with games (I was able to play Civ V just fine on the A8), but that's not a big priority for me. The "package" is much nicer than my old Acer. Sleeker, thinner, not the glossy (fingerprint magnet) finish, and a good bit lighter. Overall it's a very nice looking laptop in my opinion. Battery life seems fine to me. I was able to get 4 hrs and 20 minutes while streaming 1 half of a basketball game from WatchESPN, 2 hours of HD movie playback (from local HD), and 1 hour of general web browsing. I could've certainly eeked out more (I plugged it in when it was at 10 percent, and the brightness was at the unplugged default of 40 percent). I got about 5 hours after switching to SSD with the same type activities. Both "tests" were with 12 gigs of Ram (Kingston HyperX Impact Black 8GB 1600MHz DDR3L CL9 SODIMM 1.35V Laptop Memory (HX316LS9IB/8)) As others have mentioned, the sound is definitely good for a laptop. I haven't had the issue where things are just slightly too quiet even on full blast with this machine. It's nice. The cons are few but there. I'm not a fan of the touchpad. It sometimes doesn't seem to track quite right. That could've been due to greasy fingers or something. The tap to click (on the general trackpad) seems to register my tap only 90-ish percent of the time. And I just don't prefer the all smooth touchpads (the buttons are integrated with the trackpad). It makes it harder, for me at least, to know where I am without looking. I wasn't able to PXE boot (it might have been my server acting up), so I don't count that as a con quite yet - the option is there. I'm only connecting to my true 5ghz wireless N network at half the speed (150 instead of 300), but that's almost surely an issue with the drivers or OS. Replacing the HDD seemed like more of a pain than with past laptops, but I may just not be remembering correctly. Either way, it did involve removing all of the back screws, "prying" the keyboard off of the body, and disconnecting ribbon connectors to get to the bay. It wasn't more than a 15 minute job though. Overall, this is an EXCELLENT midlevel option. It makes me feel even worse for my family members/friends that still go to best buy and get suckered in to a 800 dollar laptop that does the exact same thing just slower.

I received my ASUS F555LA-AB31 and was amazed to find it full of bloat ware and not displaying proper 1080p resolution.  I contacted ASUS Tech Support and after trouble shooting the issue was advised to send in the computer via RMA.  I sent my laptop in and it was returned to me less than two weeks later, however the resolution issue had not been fixed, the tech had merely reloaded windows 10 again and shipped it back to me.  The RMA technician also failed to return my AC Adapter with my laptop computer so when I received it back, i received a laptop with a dysfunctional LCD panel and no charger.  I called Asus fairly infuriated and they advised me to send this laptop back to them for a second RMA.  Although I was feeling drained and ready to simply buy another better laptop I agreed to send the laptop back to them again.  Asus contacted me a few days after their receipt of my laptop with a $210.00 invoice for damage to the LCD panel that apparently isn't covered by their 1 year warranty, as well as shipping costs and explained that I would have 3 days to pay them what is essentially 65% of the original purchase price of the unit or have the unit shipped back to me unrepaired.  I understand some other individuals on Amazon have had a positive experience with this product, however I am not one of them.  Asus Technical support have seemingly done everything in their power to break or lose the components to this laptop and want me to foot what is essentially the original cost of the unit in order to have it returned to me in functional condition.  I have called Asus Tech Support at least 15-20 times over the course of the last month and rather than resolving my problem they have made it worse.  If this thing worked properly, it might be a great deal, but if you have trouble with your unit do NOT EXPECT ASUS TO BE OF ANY HELP WITH THEIR WARRANTY/RMA service.  If I were you I would AVOID the purchase of this product.  I sure wish that I had.

I needed a new laptop for general usage, and didn't want to spend a lot of money. I purchased the ASUS F555LA-AB31 for $350 not knowing what to expect due to the low price and some mixed reviews. After receiving and using it, I couldn't be happier. Out of the box, I could tell that the build quality isn't the greatest. But it was not unexpected, and I find it fine at this price point. Pretty much everything is plastic. On the plus side it makes this laptop lightweight. The keyboard and touchpad are "OK", but nothing special. The first thing I did before even booting the computer for the first time was install another 4GB of RAM. Installing it is simple as could be, and takes a minute. The 4GB included with laptop is not removable, and you can add up to another 8GB for a maximum total of 12GB. There is a reason I only added 4GB though. For best performance, I wanted all the RAM running in Dual Channel Mode. This is accomplished my making sure all the RAM installed is the same size and same speed. I purchased this SODIMM from Amazon for $20, and it works perfectly. Kingston Technology 4GB 1600MHz DDR3L PC3-12800 1.35V Non-ECC CL11 SODIMM Intel Laptop Memory KVR16LS11/4 I also confirmed with CPU-Z that the RAM is running in Dual Channel Mode. On the first boot, I carefully checked to make sure the display had no defects such as dead pixels or light bleeding. Mine was perfect. The FullHD 1090P display is bright and clear. It doesn't have the viewing angles or brightness of displays on much more expensive laptops, but It's the best display I've ever seen on a budget laptop. After booting, I let Windows 10 do it's thing and update to the latest build. After this was done, I checked the ASUS support page and updated a few drivers that were out of date. I'm impressed with the Intel Core i3-5010U 2.1GHz, Broadwell CPU. It's more than fast enough for me, and the HD 5500 Integrated Graphics is better than I expected. The 500GB 5400RPM isn't going to impress anyone, but again it was not as bad as expected. Windows boots in under 20 seconds, and everything loads in under a minute. I'm on the fence whether or not to replace it with an SSD, but for now I might just keep it. After spending a few hours tweaking Windows 10 and reinstalling all my software, I'm completely happy with the ASUS F555LA-AB31. It performs better than expected and I love the FullHD 1080P screen. I doubt I could find a better, more powerful laptop for the price.

I noticed immediately on trying to use, that the main piece of plastic for the touchpad was oriented crooked with respect to the surrounding case.  The result was that the right-click didn't work -- or rather, sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn't.  I couldn't tell because there was no discernible click, just a kind of recalcitrant mush feeling.  And even when right click worked, it took many looonnng seconds to kinda/sorta pop back up.  It was clear that someone at the manufacturer had noticed this, because there was a little nick in the surrounding case plastic near the sticky corner, where someone had used some kind of tool to get it unstuck before it was shipped.  Fixed it just long enough to shove it out the door and collect my money -- hey, it's the Chinese way!  You don't actually expect it to work, do you?

I had already returned another of these laptops, which had gotten completely crushed and obliterated in shipment -- I guess that's the UPS way.  Kudos to Amazon, though, for their painless-as-possible return policy, I really appreciated that.  I didn't want to go through another return cycle, so I used a sharp knife to shave down the edge of the crooked plastic touchpad.  I was successful, and the touchpad works fine now.  The result isn't exactly pretty, however, and serves as a daily reminder to me of Chinese manufacturing excellence.  Not!

I've had this laptop for about a month now, and I've been really impressed.  Out of the box it's fairly lightweight, if a little bulky. The size wasn't a surprise- I chose it mainly for its large screen, which is HD quality and really nice.  Since I will primarily use it at home, I don't mind the size at all, and it's still light and thin enough to carry with me as needed.  I'm not a hardcore computer user- this is my first new machine in years.  But I still managed to swap out the stock hard drive with a solid state drive, which brought the boot time down to under 10 seconds.  Amazing.  It also required a ram upgrade, which was even simpler.  It has plenty of power and memory for just about anything I need to do- and at $350 it was a deal.  Some people don't seem to like the "feel" of the keyboard or the case, but frankly I don't mind.  The ridged outer case seems to catch a lot of dust and crumbs, so that's mildly annoying, but nothing I get bent out of shape about.  For under $400 you've got yourself a really nice machine.

The reason I purchased this new notebook is because the battery on my previous five year old SONY laptop would no longer take a charge. I tried ordering a replacement battery from Amazon and it arrived dead. After much thought I decided in might behoove me to just buy a new computer and because the ASUS F555LA was considered a BEST BUY I went with it. I've only had the machine two days and for the price I'm very happy with it. HOWEVER even though I knew beforehand that the owner/user cannot replace the battery because it is internal, I figured how much could ASSUS charge a valued customer to change batteries? Well, I just called ASUS and I'll tell you how much....ready?....$330!!!!. The purchase price of this computer new from Amazon was $349.95 on 1/19/16. Granted one can always resort to plugging in the unit but the length of the power cord is rather short. So, if like myself, you like the ability to walk from room to room without plugging in the charger, you might want to consider a computer that allows you to replace the battery yourself. BTW when the ASSUS person I spoke to (who couldn't give me the overall life expectancy of the battery when asked) saw I was a bit peeved by the outrageous pricing of replacing the battery she said, "But understand sir when your battery does die and you need to have us replace it, the cost might very well change and could possibly be cheaper than the current price I've quoted you"....to what.....a mere $250.00!?!?!?! I was going to say, "Yeah, but for that matter it might even increase in price" but I decided instead to say my thanks and hung up.

*** Update to review about performance - I saw at least one person saying poor performance. The first day I got the laptop, I removed McAfee and a couple of other unneeded programs. I then installed free AVG Anti-Virus and their free trial of PC Tuneup. PC Tuneup will help you remove unneeded start-up programs and disable other programs that can affect performance. After this, we timed the laptop from powered off to windows sign-in page. It took 30 seconds. This is before adding memory and the ssd. One thing that will slow this down is Windows and other programs that are set for auto-update. If they find and download updates automatically, this can really slow down the boot up while they install updates. I turned off auto update for most software. The casual user probably shouldn't do this since it is important to keep security updates installed. After installing additional 8gb memory and ssd, laptop boots up in less than 5 seconds from power off. *** Update to battery performance. After about 3-weeks, I have discovered that I am getting 4+ hours even with the screen brightness turned up above the suggested power saving setting. The SSD may be helping some but still, the performance is very good. I am still very satisfied with the purchase. One tip to save battery power is to change what happens when you close the lid. You can find this setting by right clicking on the battery icon in the bottom right of the display. Select power options and then "Choose what closing the lid does". Changing this to hibernate while on battery power will save your open pages and programs to disk and turn off the computer. This saves a lot of battery instead of leaving the laptop in "sleep" mode. With the SSD, it only takes seconds to come back up. Sleep mode slowly drains the battery since memory has to remain powered up. *** I keep looking at other models but I have yet to find one this good in this price range. None of the others I have been looking at have the 802.11ac wifi or the 1920 x 1080 screen. I recommend this laptop to my colleagues over all others for school, business, home, video use. I usually purchase the least expensive new laptop every few years that I use for business and home. This time I decided to do more research and go for the fastest home/business laptop but at a reasonable price. I found this laptop at $349 but ended up getting one that was listed as "new" with box damage for $309. It got here fast and although it looked like it had been handled, it looks and works like new. A couple of features that this laptop has that others in the price range don't are: ** - the 802.11ac wifi (newest and fastest). Sometimes called "Gigabit WiFi", this new standard boasts throughput and data transfer speeds up to three times faster than 802.11n. If you want to have wifi that is the latest and fastest, be sure you get this. This is a feature that will keep this laptop current for the next few years. It is hard to find on others in this price range and even much more expensive. I have not once had the dreaded "buffering" delay in any video since I got this a couple of weeks ago. ** - the HD 1920 x 1080 pixel display. This is considered full HD.Most others only have 1366X768 pixels. This one provides much sharper and clearer text and video. I plan on using this to watch Prime and Netflix videos. This is another feature that none of the other laptops in this price range had. If you plan on watching videos on your laptop, this is a very valuable feature. These two features sold me on this laptop. I couldn't find these on others in this range. I wanted to make sure I bought the one that would last and not be outdated in a year or two. This was it and a couple of weeks later, I am really pleased. I also checked out the Core I3 processor and found that it was reasonably fast. In fact, faster than some older I5s and even I7s. Unless you are playing high-end games, this processor has more than enough power for Windows, Office, Turbo Tax, Quick Books, and other business programs. I also read the " Thygesen " review and info on adding memory and an SSD disk. Thank you Thygesen. I ordered the parts he suggested. Everything worked fine except the disk enclosure. It is metal and has soldered connections on the disk connector that shorted against the case when the cover was installed. I had to use it without the case on it. I am returning it and purchasing the Inateck 2.5 Inch USB 3.0 Hard Drive Disk HDD External Enclosure. Here is the Amazon page: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DW374W4?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00. Here is a list of the parts I purchased for the 8gb memory and 250gb SSD: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DW374W4?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00 HD enclosure with USB 3.0 cable http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OAJ412U?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00 Solid State Disk SSD 250 GB -Samsung 850 EVO 250GB 2.5-Inch SATA III Internal SSD http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KQCOTCM?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00 8 GB memory - Kingston HyperX Impact Black 8GB 1600MHz DDR3L CL9 SODIMM 1.35V Laptop Memory (4 GB is only $23.50 and is enough for most business users) And a carrying case with shoulder strap that had good reviews for $19.75 - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007AB9JK4?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00 Case Logic 15.6-Inch Laptop Case The Laptop was already fast out of the box but is really much faster with the extra 8gb memory (12gb total) and the SSD. I should warn you that replacing the original hard disk with the SSD is a bit nerve wracking on your new laptop. There is a good video on youtube that shows this but you should be aware that the thin ribbon cables for the keyboard and mouse pad are fragile and a bit tricky to undo and re-attach. I thought I had broken them when I opened the case and the two cables pulled loose after raising the keyboard cover. There is no typical connector on these. They just lay flat and have to be clipped into place on the board and cover. The latch is tiny. Be sure that you have the latch open - slide the cable with the exposed wiring down into the connector - then carefully push the latch closed. Here is the youtube video: [...] - Use a credit card as shown to undo the clips on the case after removing the screws. It works well and won't damage the edges like a screwdriver. I found it easiest to start by the cd player and go all the way around carefully and slowly. Adding memory is easy. Just be sure that you remove the plastic cover from the top of the screw and open the memory cover on the back. The screw cover needs to be pulled off carefully. It isn't like the rubber covers that come off and can be replaced. You scratch and lift it off and throw away. The memory goes in at a 45% angle and then you push it down until it clicks. Make sure you have it all the way into the connector with the keyed opening or slot in the correct position before pushing down. 12 GB is all you can put in the system since the original 4 GB seems to be soldered in. One more thing to be aware of is the software that the Samsung SSD comes with. The CD in the box has an older version (2.6 or 2.7) that will not work on Windows 10. Go to the Samsung site and download the 3.0 version. It works great. It will copy the hd to the ssd in about 10 minutes. You can use their Magician software to make changes to the OS that will speed up the SSD even more after installationASUS F555LA-AB31 15.6-inch Full-HD Laptop (Core i3, 4GB RAM, 500GB HDD) with Windows 10. One benefit of doing the ssd upgrade is now having the original drive as an external hard disk. It still has all the data on it and should be a good backup for the OS and bootable. I did encounter a couple of problems when attaching the HD through the USB. The drive came up as "read only" and there was a drive letter conflict(two c: drives). I fixed the drive letter problem by right clicking the start icon in the lower right corner and selecting "Disk Management". I was able to put it online and the drive letter changed to d:.. I still had a problem with the disk being read-only. The only way I was able to fix this was with "diskpart". Google this and you will find how to change the attribute to read/write. The only "con" I have for this laptop is the fact that the battery is stored inside and not removable like most laptops. I suspect that this will become more common as batteries get more reliable and last longer. After several weeks, I am getting around 3+ hours on battery. It would be longer but I prefer my screen brighter than the power saving setting so I turn this up. If you use the recommended power saving settings, you should be able to get 4-5 hours. I work with battery operated equipment for my job and batteries are getting better. Lithium batteries are now lasting 4-5 years so I hope that it what I will see in this laptop. The battery can be replaced but you will have to open the case to do it. If it does last 5 years, that will be great and it will be time for a new laptop or some other device by then. SO, I got a great laptop. Upgraded the memory and disk drive to an ssd for around $150 and even have the original 500gb hd as an external drive. Cost - about $450. Great deal and this is a product that should last for 5 years. I definitely recommend it. The only thing I would say it needs out of the box is at least 4gb more memory. It uses 2-3 gb just for the operating system and a couple of web pages open. 4 GB more memory is around $23. Since you can add 8gb more for only about $40 bucks, that is probably the way to go.

*UPDATE 27th feb 2016*
I've figured out the problem in the laptop as to the reason why it was not starting, so i've decided to share if anyone has similar problems.

If after a while your laptop has died or it came DOA. look at the bottom right of the laptop where the lights are. If you press the power button and the lights come on as usual and the screen flickers a little bit, but still won't turn on, then the motherboard has excess charge in it.

In a situation like this, get a screwdriver and remove the 10 screws on the bottom of the laptop. This loosens the keyboard section of the laptop but it will still be held into position by clips.

Starting from the top right and top left, gently pull up and undo the clips right around the laptop. work your way around the laptop until all clips are undone. BE CAREFUL THOUGH. There are two connectors connecting the keyboard and the touchpad to the laptop. These must be removed before the keyboard section comes off completely.

After removing the keyboard undo the 3 screws on the battery and remove the battery. press and hold the power button for an entire minute (this removes the excess charges that are in the motherboard) when this is finished, plug in the power adapter in the laptop and power it on (do not replace the battery as yet). If the laptop powers on, you've remedied the problem

So now i still have this great laptop with all my work, no complains anymore. Would definitely recommend to anyone looking for an amazing budget laptop.
*END OF UPDATE*

*UPDATE 23rd feb 2016*
It has been a month and a half (bought this around the 8th Jan) and now it will not turn on. It cut off randomly on me (it was plugged in so it's not the battery or the cord) and now it will not even start.

When pressing the power button, the lights flash and only 2 remain on. Those 2 are the power and the battery charging lights. The hard drive light does not blink at all. And when i press and hold the power button to power the machine off.. The 'click' youd here from the harddrive is not there. This indicates a faulty motherboard as it no longer accesses the hard drive. As a college student (computer science major) with tons of assignments due in the upcoming weeks I'm at a loss here because now I do not have a usable machine which I can use to do my assignments.

***End of update***

This PC had a good price and all the specs we wanted.  We really liked it and spent several hours setting it up.  There was one PROBLEM:  the left CTRL key kept sticking.  On some web pages and other apps this caused erratic behavior and UI issues.  So we ordered a replacement expecting the new one to not have the same annoying issue.  However, upon opening up the new identical laptop, to our DISAPPOINTMENT, the new laptop HAD THE SAME ISSUE!  This whole experience has been a huge waste of time.  It's unfortunate that the quality control process could not have rectified what would have otherwise been a great product experience.

buyers take note:
(A) this laptop is cheaper than others because it DOESN'T come with MS Office installed (no Word, etc.; note there is a free 30-day trial). Add this to your expenses when considering the purchase price.
(B) although there is a DVD player -- take note -- the driver is *not* installed on this device; I spent hours trying various downloads, none of which functioned to play the DVD. Installed a new media player from the Windows store -- the dvd still doesn't play -- even *after* updating matshita driver & making sure that "autoplay" was selected in the control panel prefs.
Sadly, this was a gift and it seemed like a great deal, with a big matte screen (which we prefer), adequate memory and processor speed.

Pros:

- Good sound
- HD screen good for multitasking, writing research papers, looking at multiple documents, using latex.
- It's not such a bad laptop if you're on a budget and are only going to use it for internet browsing and office/etc.
- Overall, I think it's the nice deal considering the specifications and the price you pay.

Cons:

- The mousepad is awful, I would recommend getting a wireless mouse to use it with. It's always zooming in and all this crap
- Windows 10 is far from a perfect OS and is pretty buggy. The laptop is 2 months old and I'm already having issues with random errors and it shutting off. As well as wifi connectivity issues. I'm extremely displeased w/ this.
- The laptop has a really cheap feel to it. Probably best left on your desk, I'm too scared it'll break if I regularly take it with me to school.

My final verdict is this: It's probably better to invest in a more quality laptop. This one makes for a nice budget laptop, but it's cheap for a reason. And if I could go back I would probably buy something better. And personally, I'm not confident how long this machine will last, and if it doesn't last long then its low buy price isn't worth it.

This computer is everything I expected it to be and more for being in the sub-$400 laptop zone. I received the laptop in less than appropriate packing from the seller (Amazon) which allowed it to be jostled about in transit. The delivery box, however, was not damaged so I wasn't overly concerned. When I got to the actual manufacturer's packaging for the laptop itself, I was very pleased to find it quite robust and sturdy.

  Laptop was came out of box gleaming and has a nice style for the price range. I plugged the laptop in before its first initial boot (per Asus's recommendation in user manual) and it started up immediately after turning power button. Once I got through the initial setup, I took it for a spin.

  Obviously for this price range, the laptop did not come with all the goodies a $1000 laptop would such as Microsoft Office or an upgraded graphics card (really, you're going to ask if you can play CSGO on a sub $400 laptop?). I had no problem with any of this since I researched what I bought before I bought it, and knew exactly what I was getting for less than $400.

  What this laptop can do very right out of the box is giving you a fast internet browser, an HD screen, and the option to add applications like Office later which is nice. I like and appreciate expandability. Inter

Give this laptop a try if you are in the market for a budget laptop with good features and quality from a reputable company.

I restarted it but to no avail -- I kept getting the blue screen reboot failure and tried everything else before finally just wiping the system and restoring it from scratch. On the second go 'round, I decided not to test it by downloading both at once again, but instead did each separately. So far, so good... I can't imagine that downloading both of those rather large items would cause such a disaster and require a complete wipe of my system, but maybe the slowdown triggered something else wonky. Hmm. Like I said, so far so good and other than minor qualms like the keyboard being a bit loud and cheap feeling (but works fine), I'm hopeful that it will be smooth sailing from here!

----------------UPDATE June 2016----------------

I'm keeping it at 3 stars. First off, the battery and sleep functions are weird.... I swear the sleep function doesn't properly work on this computer but I'm not sure how to fix it. It SHOULD mostly turn "off" and use only a liiiiittle battery while unplugged and asleep. Instead, even if I've put it to sleep and it was on full power, if I unplug it then the next time I turn on my computer (which may just be that next morning), sure enough, the battery warning sign is flashing. Argh!! Not a dealbreaker but very annoying to have to plug in so often.

Second, every 3-4 times I wake it from sleep, it takes about 10 minutes to get up and running with my same browser tabs I had opened before putting it to sleep. Maybe another thing that's wrong with the Sleep mode? I'm not sure.

Third, sometimes the keyboard doesn't register when I'm trying to click on something which is more annoying than really a deal breaker, but still.

My previous ASUS was so wonderful, and I'm pretty disappointed in this one. I'm keeping it at 3 stars rather than 2 because when it doesn't have those Sleep or keyboard issues, it's a nice computer. I like the extended keyboard, the quality of video, and sound. After the first issue with Windows 10 on the computer, I haven't had any system failures like that since then.
I really do like this laptop. It's very efficient to use and the specifications are great.

A loose screw was found in the laptop upon unpackaging it from the box.  We could hear this simply by shaking the machine lightly before first power-on.  It is unclear where this screw came from but it appears to be missing from the heatsinks tiedown or harddrive bay.  The screw is small in length and not used for structure.  However, had we not checked for foreign objects in the computer before power-on it could have created a pretty sizeable short, effectively ruining the laptop.

The laptop powered on after removal of the screw (we did this by removing all exterior structure screws, minus the one that breaks the warranty.  This gave just enough room for it to fall out).  However after this, on first power-on, we noticed the top part of the screen was ALSO damaged.

Overall -- We had TWO separate, major defects on this computer that should have been easily caught in quality.  We are calling ASUS to figure out a "prompt" return.

As a side note, I also received a separate ASUS laptop a couple months ago (direct from ASUS's online store) that will filled with paper.  Apparently someone in their packaging department stole the laptop.  Talk about a literal month of fixes to get that sorted out.

ASUS is on the way down.  Be careful in purchasing an ASUS computer while their quality control is asleep.

Works beautifully right out of the box. Touch pad is clean and smooth and sensitive. Doesn't come loaded with a million items on Startup. Very responsive. Windows 10 Feels amazing and it took only 5 minutes to complete setup.
So far I love it..

Straight out of the box, this laptop was nonfunctional. The mouse touchpad, USB ports, & headphone jack didn't work. After seven calls to tech support (got hung up on twice) and seven hours of uninstalling drivers & restarting, it still didn't work. Finally, I was told I have to send it in to be repaired. However, the tech said he couldn't give me an RMA to send it back since his computer was offline and his shift was almost over so he didn't have time to help me. So now I have to call back again tomorrow and wait in the cue again.
Love it!!!

What I like: 1) SD card slot. These are not as ubiquitous as they once were, and at this price point its a big plus for me. 2) One easily upgradable RAM slot. I mean, having one at all is a plus, but one that is easy to get into is a big plus. 3) 1920x1080p resolution. At this price point and well above, most screens are not Full-HD. This one displays crisp text and decent color. 4) VGA port. The VGA port gives this machine a much wider range of backwards compatibility with older external displays and projectors. 5) HDMI port. Current and future compatibility with external displays and projectors. 6) Ethernet port. Very happy this port is there, and for my uses of this machine it is very important. Connecting to secure networks is possible. (WiFi is NEVER secure, period.) AND if you were to use it for some light gaming its a plus too. 7) Its bloody light to carry it is.

What I don't like: 1) No indicator lights for capslock OR numlock. AWE COME ON MAN! This one omission almost, ALMOST, made me send it back; only the absolute basic human interface on this machine. 2) Keyboard is spongy and springy. It must be the least expensive way to build a keyboard, which is what this machine is all about anyway. 3) Very flimsy feeling CD/DVD tray. Again, "just functional" is what this machine is about. 4) Screen has a very narrow angle of view. Again, not surprising and not a deal breaker at this price point but, I don't like it. 5) No physical buttons for WiFi/Bluetooth/Volume, or anything else. 6)Battery life isn't long enough for two Netflix movies over WiFi. From full battery I watched "A Christmas Carol,"  and the very beginning of "The Ridiculous 6," BUT we shouldn't expect more than that at this price point. A person may not get a full day of college classes of typing out notes in Microsoft Office (especially the Cloud-based version). Extend your battery life by taking notes with Wordpad, Notepad, LibreOffice, or OpenOffice, and possibly Microsoft Office installed locally -- with the screen brightness turned down as low as you can stand it, and make them pretty with whatever you like later. If you really want longer battery life expect to pay much more for the machine. Machines in this price range and many above it just don't have fantastic battery life. If long duration "off the mains" operation is of high importance to you, this machine is not it.

Note: To extend your battery life of any "connected" device, turn off (disable in Windows) wireless technologies such as WiFi, Bluetooth, and cellular network connections when you don't need them or aren't using them. Also, be cautious of the power drain on USB connected devices if you are trying for longer battery life.

In closing: I Started my career designing and testing network hardware back in the 80's. I currently specialize in computer hardware and operating systems. -- Laptops below the $1500 point as of this writing compromise many things to be in the low price niche. There are just a few laptops that can claim all day work off the mains. With that in mind this particular machine does a great job for what it is. It is not a heavy graphics workhorse, it is not a gaming powerhouse, it is not a 12-hours-off-the-mains toiler. With the above notations, it is a light to medium duty beauty at $350. Even then, I would be willing to pay $50 more for a back lighted keyboard and capslock/numlock indicators.

I am happy! I write, research, read, study, social media if I have to--and stream movies. I use Scrivener and Word (office); write and read email. This computer does all that without issues at this time. I have to learn to "Skype" and create podcasts at some point; I do have neglected blog sites. I don't play games on line--so I don't know about that. The computer is just what I need. Sound is good for me as well. There are two "speakers" in front. Hope this helps you decide if this computer is right for you!

This is a basic no-frills Windows 10 PC laptop. I bought this for a child who doesn't have huge processing needs and doesn't need require extensive video memory. The laptop was a little slow and unresponsive at first. This is to be expected with the 4mb RAM that it ships with. I bought an additional 8mb RAM chip (the maximum allowed for this machine) which was an easy upgrade after removing the small button-looking sticker on the bottom. At 12mb of RAM, the laptop is responsive and very usable. It works great for web browsing, email, office applications, and some low-demand video games. Seems to be sturdily built and the screen is wide and looks great for this price point. Overall, very pleased.

To start off, this is my third ASUS machine that I've for myself and other family members, and I've been very happy with their long lasting reliability. My previous two were higher end machines, and this was the first time that I was looking for a laptop for a college student that didn't require as powerful of a machine. When looking for laptop, I read Thygesen's review on upgrading this machine with additional RAM and replacing the HDD with an SSD really makes this laptop cost effective and fast, so I thought I'd give it a try. Out of the box this is a decent laptop and a pretty good price. Once I made the two upgrade, I couldn't believe the increase in performance. I did a lightly instensive stress test, and this machine handled it like a champ. SSD and RAM upgrade that I chose: Samsung 850 EVO 250GB 2.5-Inch SATA III Internal SSD (MZ-75E250B/AM) Crucial 8GB Single DDR3 1600 MT/s (PC3-12800) CL11 SODIMM 204-Pin 1.35V/1.5V Notebook Memory CT102464BF160B Pros: Lovely, slim design Keyboard feels great Surprisingly great sound quality Great battery life Very easy to add additional RAM Cons: Not the biggest fan of the touchpad. The left click seems to occasionally get stuck. The HDD is kind of a pain to replace. If you're going to go this route, I would highly recommend watching a tutorial to prevent ripping any ribbon cables or damaging the casing.

For $350 you get:
HD screen rated at 1080 by 1920
4 GB of on board RAM
2.1 GHZ Dual Core processor

Like many reviewers, I chose to upgrade via:
Samsung Evo 250 GB for $80.00
8 GB of DDR3 204-PIN SDRAM (4 on board + 4 from old laptop)

As a result, anyone with basic hardware skills can do the installation and turn this $350 laptop into an similarly equipped $600+ powerhouse.

At 2.1 GHZ Dual Core, the processor is not heavy duty. Despite this, it certainly packs a capable punch to run editing software such as photoshop, Web browsing, and word processing. Augmented by a SSD and an extra stick of RAM (upgradable to 8 GB on top of the 4 GB on internal ), this laptop is sure to provide a more than sufficient experience everyday.

Moreover, given the upgrades of an ssd and a fairly light processor, the battery on this laptop can go a decent 5 hours while connected to wifi and up to 7:30 (or more) if you only need one program like Microsoft Word to write a report on airplane mode.

I have had this laptop for a month already and have never been disappointed in my purchase. I look at it with gratitude every day, knowing that it is a $600+ laptop spec wise and only had to spend an extra $80.
You need to buy this laptop right after you read this review

I really don't think that you can beat the price point and quality of this laptop. I swapped out the HDD for an SSHD Seagate 500GB Laptop SSHD SATA 6Gb/s 64MB Cache 2.5-Inch Internal Bare Drive (ST500LM000), installed Windows 7 Windows 7 Home Premium SP1 64bit, System Builder OEM DVD 1 Pack (For Refurbished PC Installation), and added a little more RAM Kingston Technology 4GB 1600MHz DDR3L PC3-12800 1.35V Non-ECC CL11 SODIMM Intel Laptop Memory KVR16LS11/4. It's not going to be future proof, but adding the extras only tacked on an extra $150ish, and it'll at least get me through the rest of my college days before it becomes terribly outdated. I would definitely recommend it! Update: It's been a couple of months now and the audio jack has quite working. I've browsed around on a few different forums and it seems that this is a common issue on newer Asus laptops. It is a hardware related issue and the only fix is to replace the main board or buy an external audio jack setup that connects via USB. Just a forewarning to anyone who has purchased or is thinking about purchasing. I'm scaling back to 4 stars because other than that this has still been a very nice laptop.

I originally ordered a Dell touchscreen laptop from Best Buy but returned it when I saw that this one has a FULL HD screen. I read Amazon reviews and I felt that I had the experience to upgrade the components as recommended in the other reviews. Namely, Crucial 8GB Single DDR3 1600 MT/s (PC3-12800) CL11 SODIMM 204-Pin 1.35V/1.5V Notebook Memory CT102464BF160B ,Samsung 850 EVO 250GB 2.5-Inch SATA III Internal SSD (MZ-75E250B/AM), and Sabrent Ultra Slim USB 3.0 to 2.5-Inch SATA External Aluminum Hard Drive Enclosure [Black] (EC-UK30). SHIPPING + PACKAGING: I received the laptop quickly but shipping box was inadequate. Asus box is placed in larger nondescript cardboard box with some packing paper placed on top. It would of been better to pack with packaging peanuts but oh well. SCREEN: Some reviewers have been writing that the HD screen is dull but that's what you get with a MATTE SCREEN! Most consumer laptops come with a gloss screen which is great for vibrant colors but for long term computer use, a matte screen is best for reduced eye strain. Albeit, the colors are more subdued but its still FULL HD!! But again, this emphasizes the value that you get from this computer. Matte screens are generally found on costlier business laptops for professionals who stare at a screen a lot. NO BLU-RAY TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE SCREEN: Keep in mind, you won't be able to enjoy Full HD DVD movies since the DVD player is NOT Blu-ray. But you can enjoy full HD movies if you're using online movie resources such as Netflix and the like. PROGRAMS: There's very little junk software loaded on the laptop which I prefer. There's Evernote, Dropbox, and Web Storage. But that's ALL there is. Tried to play a DVD but there's no Windows Media Player! It costs $15 from the App Store! But not to worry. There are excellent and not to mention, FREE alternatives. I downloaded VLC Player. You'll have to download it directly from their site and not the App Store. There's some downside when you download it from the App Store but I can't remember what it was right now. HOW-TOs: DIY How to install memory. 1. Locate small cover on bottom of laptop. 2. There is one screw on that cover that has a black sticker on top. Use flathead screwdriver to pry up the sticker. 3. Remove screw using Phillips screwdriver and lift cover. 4. Pop in RAM. Put the cover back on. Put screw back in. Put sticker back on. 5. Verify BIOS to verify that it bumped up to 12GB. If not, then make sure RAM is seated properly in motherboard. DIY How to check BIOS + bump up graphics memory. 1. Turn on computer. 2. PRESS and HOLD "SHIFT" button and then shut down the computer. Once computer is off, let go of "SHIFT" button. 3. PRESS and HOLD "F2" button and then PRESS Power button to start computer. DO NOT let go of F2 button until BIOS screen pops up. 4. Under the MAIN tab, it should show Memory Information- Total Memory as 12288MB. Yay! 5. While you're here, bump up the shared graphics memory to 512MB. Go to ADVANCED tab, Go down to graphics and then select 512. 6. Press "F10" to save and exit. DIY How to Clone Your SLOW hard drive stuff to your NEW FAST hard drive. I had some problems with this one. Thought I could use the external hard drive enclosure and the Samsung Software included with the SSD to clone. But the Samsung software does not recognize the hardware on the enclosure. You would need a direct USB to SATA III cable to connect to the SSD. Instead, I downloaded the CNET recommended free "Macrium Reflect" software and cloned the harddrive using that. Success! DIY How to Replace old hard drive with SSD. Go to Youtube "Asus F555L Disassembly for Hard Disk Replacement" and follow instructions. Keep screws in order because the lengths are different. Otherwise, you'll have difficulty figuring out which length screw goes into which hole. This is easily avoided if you place them on a clean table in a similar arrangement as they came out. I broke a few clips on the keyboard cover while removing so be prepared. This would probably have to be the only negative part about this process. Make sure to flip up the locking clips before yanking out the ribbon cables. Results: 1. I've definitely noticed faster boot time. I want to say its maybe around 5-10 seconds before you're up and running. 2. Programs open faster. 3. Of course you can now open more windows and run more programs simultaneously but I haven't tested this to its limit. 4. Boosting graphics memory probably helps but haven't noticed a difference since its new anyway. 5. Happiness since I probably would have had to spend $500 more to get something comparable to this. :) Total spent is about $460. ENJOY!!

No amount of tweaking either using the Intel tool or Windows color management helps.  It's just a lousy screen.  And beware that you are completely on your own.  There is no paper manual or starter guide.  Plug it in and begin the process of registering with Microsoft and configuring the computer.  There is a manual stored on the computer, but you have to get it operational first before being able to read it.  I wouldn't buy it again.

it is not fast but not slow either, just about right for home use in a minimal computing needs environment.  i would not want to use for heavy duty work.

it has idiosyncracies that you should consider - annoying but not too much.  if you can live with them then i believe that this computer is a very good buy.  these idiosyncracies revolve around the touchpad, mouse/cursor and keyboard.  the keyboard seems to be a membrane type - such that keystroke is short and there is limited resistance to key depression (no springs).  the touch pad does not respond well to taps (to select) if the taps are made around the edge - tap again in the center.  some mouse behavior modification is possible by using the "mouse" and "ease of access" applets found in the control panel (eg i made the mouse solid black so it is easier to find on white background documents, also decreasing the speed of mouse movement was useful to me).

i also noticed that leaning on the left side of the device (to the left of the touch pad) made the touchpad behave erratically - probably due to collateral touchpad input.  leaning on the right side also makes the touch pad behave erratically, just not as much.  this computer is one where the design was focused on minimum cost and the touchpad was an area where performance trade-offs were made.

i found that the response lag was improved by turning off and/or deleting unused apps.  i recommend turning them off as opposed to deleting because you may need them later.  they can always be turned on briefly for use at a specific point.

windows 10 is good.

the left and right mouse keys are not separate keys, they are part of the touchpad surface which means that the touchpad surface extends touch response such that finger movement is tracked in the left/right button area.  this means that you can get odd interactions and selections when you are not expecting them.  this also means that you need to keep your finger motionless if you are selecting something via pressing keys at the bottom of the touchpad (otherwise movement of your finger on the touchpad keys is interpreted by the computer as cursor movement).  the way to cope with this is to try to keep finger movements near centered in the touchpad when moving the cursor.

many reviewers commented on the low quality screen.  my take is that given the minimum cost focus of the design that a lower end but adequate screen has been used.  it is more than adequate for general computing without intensive video.  you should not plan to use the screen for displaying high quality video, it will display them but not with the quality you may want.

despite the idiosyncracies i like the computer and the price/performance trade-offs.  you would be really hard-pressed to find a better laptop at the price.

PROS:

  Screen is one of the best for the price range

CONS
  Even though this is a 1080p panel it is most likely a TN panel. Viewing angles are shallow and color reproduction will seem off for those who have an eye for such things
  Screen could do with being brighter, fine for indoor use but may be a problem in the sun
  Speakers are not that great, most likely due to their position, Recommend earbuds or external speakers
   This laptop would be greatly improved by an SSD. A 5400 rpm hard drive makes for slow boots and longer load times
  Laptop lacks a Caps Lock or Num Lock light. This paired with lack of a keyboard backlight could cause slower typing and more mistakes for some

Overall this laptops has it cons but simply can not be beat for this price. I would recommend this to most people on the hunt for a budget laptop.

I purchased this laptop for a very specific purpose which is to run Wireshark and Nmap on Fedora 23. The items that were important to me were:

1: 15+inch and 1920x1080 resolution
2: 10/100/1000 network interface
3: 8GB RAM minimum
4: USB3
5: Intel i3+ processor
6: ability to run Fedora 23, Wireshark, Nmap and RealVNC client
7: ability to sleep/wake with lid closing/opening in Fedora 23 without screen freezing

The first thing I did was to go through the default setup to finish the Windows installation. Then I selected to make a USB backup of the system. I chose to include everything so I can restore back to original condition if need be. This required an 8GB+ USB stick. I'll never use Windows and only created the USB as a fail safe if I need to return the machine.

I then rebooted into the BIOS and set the video ram to 512MB, it's on 32MB by default. Next I booted from a Fedora 23 USB stick and went through the installation. On first start Fedora 23 prompted me for my Wi-Fi connection and password, then connected with no issues. This surprised me. I hadn't added any repo's yet and expected issues with the Wi-Fi setup. I had no such issues. Everything worked out of the box using Fedora-Live-Workstation-x86_64-23-10.iso with GNOME3. No need to compile wireless drivers or add rpmfusion to get up and running. Nice.

As for the quality of the laptop itself, it's very important to remember the cost of this laptop and that it has a 1920x1080 display resolution. There has to be trade-offs at this price. The trade-off for the FullHD resolution is a very poor viewing angle. For me this is not an issue. The text is crisp, clear and has good contrast. There is quite a bit of light bleed around the edges. Again, for me this is not an issue. It might be for you. This is not a high quality display and it's not marketed as one. If I had spent another two hundred on it, I wouldn't find the display acceptable.

As for the hard-drive, it's no speed demon, but it's fine. I'll probably rip the back off (that YouTube video makes me cringe) and throw in an SSD at some point.

At home I use a mechanical keyboard and at work I use an Apple keyboard. This one won't bother me. It's acceptable.

I think Asus did a fine job on this three hundred and thirty dollar laptop and I only have 2 things I "wish" they had done differently. I wish they had left the DVD drive back in 2012 where it belongs. I haven't used a DVD in well over 3 years. DVD is dead and it's a break point on this machine. Every time I pick it up I feel it, it's going to break off at some point. I realize with the FullHD display and DVD drive it makes it more preferable to the target market. In fairness I'm not the target market.

My other "wish" would be a back-lit keyboard. I work in a lot of dark area's and for the most part the light from the display is enough, but it would have been a nice touch. Other than that I can't complain, I consider this to be a pretty ideal machine for what I need it for.

Like several other reviewers I purchased the extra 8GB of RAM.12GB RAM will be overkill for my needs but RAM is cheap. Installation was simple, less than 60 seconds.

The ease of installation with Fedora 23 tells me I bought the right machine for my needs.

Pros:
-Windows 10, no need to deal with iOS
-Intel i3 CPU is only slightly weaker than my old $650 Asus laptop from 2012 that was Intel i5.
-GPU is Intel HD 5500, will handle any game up to old (the good) Call of Duties, but this laptop is only $350, don't expect anything fancy.
-RAM is standard 4GB. Not really a pro, but not a con, either.
-Storage is a 500GB HDD, which is a fair amount. I would still buy for $400 if it had a 250GB SSD.
-Easily portable, won't bend easily if I pick it up with one hand gripped on one side (still not a recommended handling habit, though).
-Battery life is above average, but not anything special.
-15.6" 1080p screen works pretty well. Not a touchscreen, so almost no need to clean it.
-Keyboard is relatively quiet and easy to clean.
-Mouse pad left and right clicks are together with the pad itself, mostly maintenance free. Pretty quiet, too.
-You can play DVDs!
-VGA input allows you to use the laptop on another display device.
-Built-in wireless adapter works well, has given me relatively few connection timeouts.
-3.5mm audio jack has a nearby USB port for gaming headsets.

Cons:
-Caps lock and num lock keys don't light up (in my knowledge, anyway).
-Mouse pad tracking performance is average, don't expect it to be amazing. It feels like it has cursor acceleration, which sucks.
-Sweat can still build up on the silver pad where your palms sit, causing discomfort during extended typing/gaming.

Nowhere does it explain that you have no anti virus software on this computer.  I have purchased 3other computers in the past and they always came with a trial membership of protection.  How would you even turn one on to purchase antivirus software if you did not have something to protect it. This purchase was a replace for my father-in-laws aging 17in C2D toshiba laptop.  I would say the new machine is about 10 times faster than the old one. The machine didn't power on out of the box but that was due to it needing to be charged.  After letting it charge overnight, it powered on right away.  Took about 15 minutes for all the windows 10 initial setup to complete and we were able to get all his data transferred right away.  He's been happy about it so far.

If you are looking for an affordable laptop for basic use, this is a very good buy. I would recommend it to anyone who needs a laptop for typically everyday use: surfing the web, streaming movies or music,c basic use programs (ie. Microsoft Office), or any other activity that doesn't require heavy processing power.

One of the main draws is the screen. For a laptop with this price tag you don't expect a crisp 1080p screen. Which makes this laptop perfect for streaming a movie if you are stuck somewhere while traveling. The battery life is usually around four to five hours as long as you aren't doing something performance heavy which is respectable, especially for this price tag.

The only problem I have with this laptop would be the touch-pad. It feels very cheaply made. I wouldn't expect it to be super high quality but it still has to be functional. I find it hard to move the cursor sometimes and the sensitivity can vary. Sometimes a light breeze will cause it to click, and sometimes you have to push really hard for it to register. The buttons on the touch-pad are incredibly loud which can be very annoying.

With that being the only problem I have with this laptop I would definitively recommend this laptop if you are looking for something cheap.

Ordered this laptop yesterday, says will be arriving Tuesday! After reading pages of reviews and doing what research I could on this product, I ordered a 250gb Samsung SSD, a 8gb stick of RAM, a SATA to USB 3.0 cord (I didn't have one or a dock already), and an empty aluminum case to place the new hdd in for a new external drive. With these upgrades and paying close attention to detail when doing the SSD, I don't see how this laptop could be short of awesome, except if your a hardcore gamer and need the faster FPS. CANT WAIT! Will update soon! Here are the links to the additional products I ordered: Samsung 850 EVO 250GB 2.5-Inch SATA III Internal SSD (MZ-75E250B/AM) Kingston HyperX Impact Black 8GB 1600MHz DDR3L CL9 SODIMM 1.35V Laptop Memory (HX316LS9IB/8) StarTech.com USB 3.0 to 2.5" SATA III Hard Drive Adapter Cable w/ UASP - SATA to USB 3.0 Converter for SSD/HDD - Hard Drive Adapter Cable Sabrent Ultra Slim USB 3.0 to 2.5-Inch SATA External Aluminum Hard Drive Enclosure [Silver Aluminum Finish] (EC-UM30) **UPDATE** Received everything on time and as described. Let me begin by saying that the whole process of upgrading the computer was seamless with these products. Here is what I did or observed during the process: 1. Unboxed everything and checked for obvious signs of damage. Plugged the PC in, went through the setup process that new pc's entail. 2. Desktop was super clean, no bloatware and crap no one needs, just the recycle bin. 3. I had a USB stick with music and video on it and tested each USB port by playing music or video, the speakers, volume controls (both keyboard and tray icon), HDMI output (which I had to dumb down the resolution in order to get the screen to properly fit on my 40" 720p Samsung HDTV), headphone jack, and dvd/cd tray open/close operation (which seems a little flimsy). Tested all the keys to make sure they work. 4. Shut PC down then installed the extra 8g stick of RAM through the only hatch on the bottom of the PC. 5. Turned back on, looked up system info to verify 12g RAM exists 5. Downloaded the software onto the pc that came with the Samsung SSD, which involves 2 utilities, Magician and Data Migration. The Migration utility will need to be updated (it prompts you to do so) 6. Hooked up the new SSD with the USB to SATA cable and opened the Migration software. Both drives come up, the HDD as source disk, and the SSD as the Target disk. Press START to start the clone process. There is a prompt warning that the target disk data will be erased. 7. It was slow to start at first, so walked away and came back 3 mins later and it was 90% done. There was about 25 gigs of files copied. 8. The program prompts you to shut down the PC, unplug the SSD, then install it. I looked "ASUS F555L ssd upgrade' and watched a short youtube video how to get into the PC. (PAY ATTENTION) It was fairly straightforward and not too much of a challenge but you could do damage to some sensitive wiring if not careful. NOTE* You do NOT need to remove the extra RAM installed or the screw to that hatch to get the PC apart. 9. Installed the SSD and restarted the computer. Booted to log screen in 3 seconds, maybe faster. SICK. 10. Open the Magician utility and run the optimizer for whichever setting you chose. I chose Performance. 11. After that I did the normal removal of apps and programs I won't use, like the Twitter app and Candy Crush Sage, did some downloading and copying of files from my external harddrive (a few pics and about 40g of music, which I am going to put on a USB 128g Cruzer Fit once it arrives. I was surprised how easy the upgrading was. I'm no beginner but the steps involved certainly can be done by one. Everything is working so fast. I am very pleased with the sound, despite some other users comments about it sucking. It may not blare like desktop speakers, but the depth of sound is fantastic and I am again very pleased. The keyboard markings are a little darker which makes them harder to see in lower light and the number pad keys aren't as big as the normal keyboard keys which, working with Excel a lot, kinda sucks for me, but purely my own preferences. The screen is beautiful and bright, and yes, sometimes you have to adjust the screen by pulling or push it back to get the best view. The only thing that did not work for me was when I hooked the HDD, the one I took out of the new pc and replaced with the SSD, into the external case, then connected it to the pc, it will not recognize the drive. So I will troubleshoot that and hopefully can use that eventually as a backup drive. ***UPDATE*** was getting an error that the drive is having a collision with a signature drive that is online so youtubed that as well and its a simple fix with a few clicks. Can fully use the HDD as an external, but make sure you separate those windows files (i.e. place in a new folder) on the 'old' HDD from any new files you store on the disk. Overall, I was skeptical about spending the money and tearing into a brand new computer but I can say 110% I am VERY PLEASED with the ASUS F555L and the upgrades I performed.

Review from a former computer store owner (10yrs) who has seen it all.

First, I think this laptop is an incredible value and more than most folks will need. I upgraded RAM to 12GB and it is more than equipped to handle most modern operations other than high end gaming/graphics. I am pleased with this buy.

However, there are some glaring shortcomings.

1. The webcam is utterly horrendous. They might as well have left it off - I had a better webcam back in 1999. Fail.

2. The hard drive (and battery!) is only accessed after removing keyboard/bezel - this allows for a thinner design but I am not pleased that I must void my warranty to upgrade to SSD. Not cool!

3. The most annoying, absolutely unacceptable problem I encountered - after testing thoroughly with just RAM upgrade I was satisfied laptop was functional and successfully upgraded to SSD. To my horror, only after drive upgrade did I test headphone jack and discover it was not working! Fearing I had damaged the board (adjacent to HD) my experience nevertheless led me to an hour's experimentation with drivers (unpaid!) and to my relief the problem was solved:

**If your headphone jack/speakers are not working - you must remove current Realtek Audio driver and roll back to the previous version on Asus's website!**

So overall I think this is some great hardware for your dollar, but it is absolutely unacceptable that the machine wouldn't be fully functional on arrival! Folks who don't know how to replace a driver might have to spend an extra $40 at their local computer shop to get this cleaned up...
Fast delivery.  Getting it set up, but so far, so good!

In addition, to the typical email, browsing, and Office, I use my laptop for streaming HD videos, which I view via HDMI to my TV. After my 2009 17" Macbook started failing, I thought I'd buy a new 13" Macbook. Unfortunately, that model's max resolution is only 1440 x 900. So I searched for a low-cost Windows 10 laptop to tide me over until Apple upgrades their 13".

The ASUS F555LA-AB31 fit the bill perfectly. It took a bit of tinkering with Windows 10 settings to get the graphics to my liking.

For those of you have a problem with how small the text is at maximum resolution:
Go to "Settings"> "System"> "Display"> "Advanced Display Settings"> "Advanced Sizing of Text and Other Items". Then click "set custom scaling level". Then increase the percentage to 125% or 150% as you wish (It says "not recommended", but it's been fine for me). In this same Settings window, I also increased the font size of each of the options by 1 point. Now the text size is comfortable. Oh one last thing, I use Chrome as my browser and set the default zoom to 110%.

Like other commenters, I found the trackpad to be a little squirrelly, and sometimes unresponsive. I first reinstalled the Asus trackpad driver, which solved the responsiveness problem. I still had problems with the scrolling gesture sometimes being interpreted as zooming. I used the Asus Smart Gesture app from Windows Control Panel and disabled the "Zoom" feature (which I use with touch screen devices, but don't need in a laptop). Now everything works great.

So, no it's not a Macbook, but for over $1000 less and a bit of time adjusting the settings, this laptop is amazing!

I was looking for a good value in a standard laptop and have to say the F555LA fits perfectly. I paid less that three-hundred fifty dollars for the laptop, and then added about two hundred dollars of upgrades.

This laptop comes with Windows 10 Home, which runs excellently, and there was no junkware that instantly had be removed. As I wanted a dual boot Windows/Linux system, I shrank the preconfigured Windows disk partition and tried to install CentOS 7. Unfortunately, there did not seem to be any Linux device driver available for the Realtek Wifi card, which does work pretty well on Windows.

A little research said I could get some upgrades, that were totally Linux compatible, although installation would be a bit painful. I ordered a 500 GB SSD (Samsung 850 EVO), 8 GB of RAM (Kingston KVR16LS11/8), and an Intel mini-PCIe Wifi card 7260. HMWG. There is a video on Youtube on how to open the laptop and replace the disk drive. The RAM is accessible from the outside through a little door on the bottom. The Wifi card is the hardest one. While its open for the disk driver upgrade, you need to take out the battery (4 screws), and the mainboard (dont forget the screw for the fan. You can leave the cable to the display connected and just flip up the mainboard enough to unscrewed one screw on the Wifi card, pop out the old one and pop in the new one. Ive never removed the mainboard on a laptop before, although am very experienced with hardware upgrades. Things are small and delicate, but all I needed was a small screwdriver and plastic pry tool to open the case, and replace the disk and wifi card. I guess this means serviceability is good, although I see a replacement mainboard costs way more than I paid for the whole computer new. Assuming a replacement battery part is available in a few years, this also proved to me that non-removable battery will not be a problem. Unlike on an Apple laptop, if my laptop dies, I could remove the disk drive and get at my data if needed, and the 8 GB SODIMM and WiFi card might also be reused someday. I also picked up a laptop disk to USB 3 adapter for a dozen bucks, so the original 500 GB spinning disk drive is now a disk for backups.

The new parts work perfectly. Windows 10 boots in under 10 seconds. Good job to Microsoft on making the Win 10 licensing easy, I just installed Win 10 onto the SSD from a DVD (this laptop still has a real DVD reader/writer) and it just figured out it was licensed for Window 10 Home, no key needed. Linux has in kernel tree drivers for the Intel Wifi card, and already had drivers for the Realtek gigabit Ethernet card also on the laptop. A note about the 8 GB ram, Asus says it only supports a 4 GB ram upgrade, which is true if you want to enable dual memory controller channels. There is 4 GB soldered on the main board, and adding a 8 GB SODIMM causes the memory controller to not configure in interleaved mode. Single memory controller mode (onboard 4 GB only or onboard + 8 GB SODIMM) gives about 12 GBytes/sec of memory bandwidth, and dual channel (if you used onboard + 4 GB SODIMM) should give about 24 GBytes/sec, although for most uses, there is not a lot of application performance difference. For many uses, 12 GBytes total ram will give way better overall performance than 8 GBytes, even if that 12 GBytes is slower. The new Intel Wifi card also works a bit better under Windows too, specifically MIracast screen sharing now works (it didn't with the Realtek Wifi). In Windows 10, I can say share my screen with my Roku 3 player, and it works well. Linux compatibility was the real reason for the Wifi upgrade, and since I was going through the pain of opening it up put in the SSD.

As others have said, the screen is not an IPS display, so its viewing angle is limited (very usable, but definitely not as nice as a MacBook Pro). There is also no keyboard backlight, so its pretty hard to type in a  dark room. I did plug the HDMI connection into my 4K TV and it worked perfectly (HDMI 1.4, 4K@30fps). It even worked to stream 4K video from youtube with cpu usage that must mean hardware accelerated playback. The processor is a Broadwell i3-5010U which cpu benchmark sits say is about 75% of the performance of the I5-4258U in my 13 MacBook Pro (late 2013). Considering my upgraded F555LA has twice the SSD storage, and 50% more ram, at about 35% of the price of the MacBook Pro, it seems like a good value. My laptop even came with TPM 2.0, even though the box said no TPM (although Windows 10 Home does not support disk encryption)

Is this the best laptop, no, but for about five hundred fifty bucks, I got a very decent performing laptop with an ok 1080P screen, 500 GB SSD, 802.11AC Wifi compatible with Windows and Linux, a wired gigabit Ethernet port and DVD read/write drive. My only real question is why cant I buy a preconfigured system with all this + an IPS screen and backlit keyboard in the $600-$700 range. I have to believe the price I pay for a SSD in a retail store is a lot more than ASUS/Dell/HP/Lenovo can buy them for. If I could just buy it preconfigured, it would also not need warranty destroying upgrades.

Without any of these upgrades the ASUS F555LA is still just an incredible value at a third of kilobuck. This is not a lot more than a low end Chromebook. The only upgrade I really needed for Linux compatibility was the twenty five dollar WiFi card.

This is a really nice laptop for the price (I'm writing this review on it). Perfect for general use applications - internet, streaming media, productivity apps - but I haven't tested it for gaming and wouldn't imagine it would be much of a performer in that respect.

Build quality is fine, if mostly plastic, but the brushed aluminum keyboard face is really slick. I've had it running on the charger for entire work days and it never even gets warm. I've never heard so much as a whisper of fan noise, but again, I'm not putting it through any intensive paces.

Windows 10 runs great on it. Never had any crashes or major hiccups. Boot up time is a little on the slow side, but nothing to write home about, and once it's up and running it never lags noticeably.

The only major flaw I've found in a month (and the reason I docked a star) is with the keyboard. It feels somewhat flimsy, with noticeable flex in the chassis when you type. And it has a really annoying habit of missing key strokes. Like, a lot. In the process of writing this review it has missed four key strokes. At first I thought it was just my fingers getting used to the keyboard but now I'm certain it's not.

I still recommend this laptop for anyone on a budget. If the keyboard annoys you it's all too easy to plug in an external one.
